Legacy 'unlimited' NASA pioneer Katherine Johnson honored during public memorials

Autor: Jones, Matt. 

Información de publicación: Daily Press ; Newport News, Va. [Newport News, Va]. 08 Mar 2020: A.1.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/legacy-unlimited-nasa-pioneer-katherine-johnson/docview/2373481075/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Legacy+%27unlimited%27+NASA+pioneer+Katherine+Johnson+honored+during+public+memorials&amp;author=Jones%2C+Matt&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.1&amp;date=2020-03-08&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Daily+Press&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Asoutheastnews_

Texto completo: HAMPTON -Rev. Brian Blount didn't know what Katherine Goble Johnson had accomplished at NASA Langley Research Center when he started as pastor at Carver Memorial Presbyterian Church in 1981.
At 24, he was nervous to be in one of his first leadership roles. But Johnson, a pioneering mathematician in the era of Jim Crow who helped take American astronauts to the moon, treated him like he'd been preaching for decades.
"She honored me the way she should have been honored when she was first starting out," said Blount, now president of Union Presbyterian Seminary in Richmond.
Over 700 people gathered Saturday morning at the Hampton University Convocation Center to celebrate the life of Johnson - a mathematical genius, an African American hero, a faithful church leader, a loving mother and a trusted confidant.
"Grandma, because of you, our world will forever be unlimited," said Michael Moore, Johnson's grandson. "And because of you, I have no bounds."
Johnson's death Feb. 24 at the age of 101 at The Hidenwood retirement community in Newport News drew national attention. Her obituary ran on the front page of The New York Times: "NASA's Shining Star, Undiscovered for Decades."
Her family received an outpouring of tributes; some were read by Carver Presbyterian clerk of session Robin Rattley during the service.
Former President Barack Obama, who awarded her the Presidential Medal of Freedom in 2015, called her a "hero to millions" in a letter to her family. First Lady Melania Trump said she "took our nation to remarkable heights."
Friends and family traveled from across the country to the Peninsula for two days of public memorials. Public viewings were held Friday in southeast Newport News, including one at Carver Presbyterian before a ceremony held by her sorority, Alpha Kappa Alpha.
Johnson was a diamond member of AKA, with over 85 years of membership. She was initiated in 1934 as a student at what is now West Virginia State University, where she graduated at the age of 18 with degrees in mathematics and French.
Dozens of her sorority sisters filled rows of Convocation Center, wearing pink corsages. They carried the floral arrangements ahead of Johnson's family during the recession.
Winnifred Magee, a kindergarten teacher in New Orleans and a friend of one of Johnson's grandchildren, drove 17 hours to attend the service.
"I can't miss this opportunity to come and share in this experience," Magee said. "I think it's historical."
Her historic role in the American space program - the woman whose calculations early astronauts trusted more than computers - was no secret to those at NASA Langley. Director Clayton Turner delivered remarks at the service and presented her family the flag that was flying over the center when she died.
Three black astronauts inspired by Johnson also spoke - Yvonne Cagle, Leland Melvin and Mae Jemison, the first black woman in space.
"I had to be here also with my colleagues because she is a colleague," Jemison said.
Melvin said he first met Johnson as a young engineer at NASA Langley, a few years after she retired. To Melvin and Cagle, she was a trusted confidant. Melvin, with permission from Johnson's daughters, called her "mom."
"I think about the journey that she's going on now," Melvin said. "We can't calculate the speed that she's traveling to get to heaven."
Despite the role she played, Johnson spent much of her life in relative obscurity, retiring from NASA Langley in 1986.
For her family at Carver Presbyterian, she was a faithful elder who led the youth choir, represented the church in Presbyterian Church's General Assembly and held a variety of leadership roles. Blount called her possibly the most overqualified church finance committee chair of all time.
"Her genius and legend may have been hidden from me, but not her abiding faith, not her genuine love," Blount said.
Rep. Bobby Scott said during the ceremony that he knew Johnson and her second husband, James Johnson, for years before he read Margot Lee Shetterly's book "Hidden Figures" about Johnson and her colleagues' work as "human computers." His father grew up going to Carver Presbyterian.
"There are few people who fought as good a fight, finished as difficult a course and all along kept the faith as Katherine Johnson," Scott said.
But the accomplishments recounted by friends and family Saturday run deeper and farther than NASA Langley.
She started high school at the age of 10, before her family moved 125 miles so that she could go to high school. She was one of three students who integrated West Virginia University's graduate school.
She raised three daughters while working at NASA. She mentored many people, including a young woman who was in juvenile detention through a program at Carver Presbyterian.
Johnson was a teacher to the end. Her daughter, Joylette Hick, said that a month ago, she was teaching one of her friends how to teach French.
"It is the end of a long and glorious life and the beginning of a new time, without her," said her other living daughter, Katherine Moore. "This is where the role model for strength and determination must become real. We all have to keep going and hang in there because she wants nothing less.
"Mom, you're taking your final trip. Safe landing. We love you."
Matt Jones, mjones@dailypress.com
Caption: Family gathers around the casket of Katherine Johnson at the start of a memorial service in her honor on Saturday at the HU Convocation Center.
Jonathon Gruenke/Staff file
Katherine Johnson, the former NASA Langley "human computer" who went from hidden figure to national celebrity.

Can you hire hit man on dark web? Experts who have studied these sites say they are scams

Autor: Popper, Nathaniel. 

Información de publicación: South Florida Sun - Sentinel ; Fort Lauderdale, Fla. [Fort Lauderdale, Fla]. 08 Mar 2020: A.14.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/can-you-hire-hit-man-on-dark-web-experts-who-have/docview/2373480904/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Can+you+hire+hit+man+on+dark+web%3F+Experts+who+have+studied+these+sites+say+they+are+scams&amp;author=Popper%2C+Nathaniel&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.14&amp;date=2020-03-08&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=South+Florida+Sun+-+Sentinel&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Asoutheastnews_

Texto completo: SAN FRANCISCO - On a website called Azerbaijani Eagles, you can commission a murder for $5,000. The site Slayers Hitmen provides more options, with a beating going for $2,000. Death by torture costs $50,000.
But don't expect someone to get the job done. Experts and law enforcers who have studied these sites - almost all of them on the so-called dark web or dark net - say they are scams. There has not been a known murder attributed to any of them.
That doesn't mean the sites aren't involved in a very dark trade. They have become catch points for real people who are looking to pay to have someone killed. And a number of men and women are sitting in jail after paying one of these sites - and getting caught by police.
In one of the most recent cases to make its way through the courts, a nurse from Illinois was sentenced to 12 years in prison after pleading guilty to sending $12,000 in bitcoin to the site Sicilian Hitmen International Network. She had hoped to have the wife of her boyfriend killed.
Twenty-four hit-man-for-hire sites are the subject of an academic paper that was shared in advance with The New York Times by Michigan State University professor Tom Holt and student Ariel Roddy.
The paper is the first academic effort to illuminate what has been a subject of endless intrigue. For years, the potential anonymity granted by the internet has fed predictions that there would be marketplaces for death and assassination.
But it was the emergence of the dark web over the past decade or so that allowed hitman sites to proliferate. Unlike most sites on the traditional internet, dark-web sites use technology that allows both sides of an online interaction to hide their identity and location, from each other and law enforcement.
"It's a fantastic opportunity to defraud people because you give them just enough sense of danger," said Emily Wilson, head of research at Terbium Labs, a security company focused on the dark net. "What are you going to do if they don't go through with it?"
When the first hit-man sites were discovered, an assumption was that the dark web was crawling with legitimate assassins waiting to kill on command.
Promotional material posted to the mainstream internet played on that assumption. One site, which provides readers with a link to the dark net address of the 18th Street Gang, holds itself out as a "guide to real hit men, facts and stories." The site claims that people who say hit-man sites are scams are just trying to discourage people from seeking them out.
"Most customers order from reliable hit men sites that have been proven as legitimate," the site says.
On many of the sites examined by the team at Michigan State, considerable effort was expended trying to prove their legitimacy so customers would feel comfortable making a payment in Bitcoin, the digital currency. Hit men are not the sort of thing you pay for with a credit card.
The site 18th Street Mafia includes a page with links to news stories about real killings it says it helped commit. None of the articles, however, indicate that the site, or even a hit man, was responsible.
The site says: "We can provide video proof of our services, with time stamps. Again, such proof is not possible for fake services."
The 18th Street Mafia did not respond to requests for comment.
The representative for another site, Darkmamba, said in an email that proving its legitimacy had been difficult because "the point of our services and many other, including underground criminal forums, is to indeed complete the job without leaving anything that could get traced back to us."
The most prolific research on these sites has been conducted by Chris Monteiro, a systems administrator in London who has pursued his investigations as a morbid passion project on top of his regular job.
Monteiro hacked into one of the sites created by the most notorious purveyor of assassination sites, a figure going by the name Yura.
After breaking into the Besa Mafia site and a few others, Monteiro found information about 283 people who had paid for hit-man services. He also found messages suggesting that the operators had little intention of going through with the killings.
"I need you to help me do some videos to prove the Besa Mafia legit, but WITHOUT killing anyone," the operator wrote in one email, trying to get a contractor to produce lifelike videos. "I am not a murderer and I don't want anyone be murdered."
Law enforcement agencies around the world have been hesitant to collaborate with Monteiro or use his evidence because of the way he acquired it. But Monteiro has worked with media organizations, including Wired and 48 Hours, which have passed his information to law enforcement officials, eventually leading to the arrests of people who paid the sites to connect them with a hit man.
Monteiro has identified nine cases in which people he exposed were arrested in connection with commissioning hits. In one of the most gruesome cases, a man in Minnesota was arrested after he was found to have killed his wife himself when the hit man he had commissioned on the Besa Mafia website for about $6,000 in bitcoin did not come through.
A police investigator in Russia is believed to have been killed by two teenagers who were hired by a drug trafficker on the dark net. An investigation by the BBC found that the killing had been commissioned on one of the broad marketplaces on the dark net where drugs and stolen credit cards are sold.
But there has still not been a killing commissioned on one of the dedicated hit-man-for-hire sites.
"Why would you set up a dedicated site online when you know absolutely that law enforcement are going to be flooding that site trying to find you?" Wilson said. "You are making yourself too big of a target."
Still, the sites have continued to proliferate. A few months ago, a middle-age executive in Singapore was sent to jail for five years after paying the Camorra Hitman site to kill the boyfriend of his young ex-lover in a staged car accident that, not surprisingly, didn't happen.
Wilson, of Terbium Labs, said these sites took attention from the real crime being committed on the dark net, such as the drug markets and the sites selling the sensitive personal information of millions of Americans.
"There is actual crime, but we are too busy talking about some guy who wants to kill his ex-girlfriend's new boyfriend," she said.
Caption: A collection of online stores offer murder for pay, but researchers say they are scams.
The New York Times

Why Hank Azaria retired Apu on 'The Simpsons' CELEBRITIES

Autor: Pineda, Dorany. 

Información de publicación: Orlando Sentinel ; Orlando, Fla. [Orlando, Fla]. 08 Mar 2020: A.2.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/why-hank-azaria-retired-apu-on-simpsons/docview/2373480882/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Why+Hank+Azaria+retired+Apu+on+%27The+Simpsons%27+CELEBRITIES&amp;author=Pineda%2C+Dorany&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.2&amp;date=2020-03-08&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Orlando+Sentinel&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Asoutheastnews_

Texto completo: Hank Azaria recently said goodbye to one of television's most beloved but also controversial animated characters. And he's finally explaining why.
Azaria, who is perhaps best known for bringing to life Apu in the long-running sitcom "The Simpsons," told The New York Times in a recent interview that he made his decision after many years of reflecting, processing and listening to the voices of people who explained why Apu was hurtful.
"Once I realized that that was the way this character was thought of, I just didn't want to participate in it anymore," Azaria said. "It just didn't feel right."
For three decades, the actor has voiced dozens of inhabitants of the fictional town of Springfield. But Apu is perhaps the most problematic, especially through a modern lens: He is an immigrant from India who owns the local Kwik-E-Mart convenience store and is known for his catchphrase, "Thank you! Come again!" His thick Indian accent and singsong voice depict him as simple-minded, and even his last name, Nahasapeemapetilon, has been thought to welcome ridicule.
Through the years, "The Simpsons" actor and the show faced increasing criticism from people who find the character an offensive, racial stereotype. Many of the critics are of Indian descent.
The show's executive producers told The New York Times in a statement that they "respect Hank's journey in regard to Apu. We have granted his wish to no longer voice the character."
But the fate of Apu remains unknown.
"Apu is beloved worldwide. We love him too. Stay tuned," the statement added.
Azaria first announced he was retiring the convenience store proprietor in January on the website /Film.
During an appearance on "The Late Show With Stephen Colbert" in 2018, Azaria addressed the mounting controversy and added that he was "perfectly willing and happy to step aside and transition (Apu) into something new ... it just feels like the right thing to do to me."
Azaria was initially unwilling to hear the arguments about why Apu's character was divisive, he told The New York Times. But he started listening and now believes his experience can spark more dialogue about representation in popular culture.
"What happened with this character is a window into an important issue," said Azaria. "It's a good way to start the conversation. I can be accountable and try to make up for it as best I can."
Caption: Willy Sanjuan/Invision

Biden, Bloomberg lie about Trump, coronavirus

Información de publicación: Rochester Democrat and Chronicle ; Rochester, N.Y. [Rochester, N.Y]. 08 Mar 2020: A.2.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/biden-bloomberg-lie-about-trump-coronavirus/docview/2373480633/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=unknown&amp;atitle=Biden%2C+Bloomberg+lie+about+Trump%2C+coronavirus&amp;author=&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.2&amp;date=2020-03-08&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Rochester+Democrat+and+Chronicle&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anortheastnews1_

Texto completo: Things spreading across the globe: coronavirus, the lies being told by Democrats about it and liberal cheerleading when something bad happens because of it.
The virus has reached 22 states in the United States (although it is reasonable to assume that many more cases will emerge in the coming weeks). But that hasn't stopped the American left from saying outlandish things about the Trump administration's response.
Joe Biden, who claims to be the antithesis to Trump's dishonesty, tried to incite public panic while campaigning in South Carolina.
"We increased the budget of the CDC. We increased the NIH budget. ... (Trump's) wiped all that out. ... He cut the funding for the entire effort," Biden said, harkening back to his days as Barack Obama's vice president.
Not to be outdone, Mike Bloomberg, who claims to be the antithesis to Trump's incompetence, went even further:
"There's nobody here to figure out what the hell we should be doing. And (Trump's) ... defunded Centers for Disease Control, CDC, so we don't have the organization we need. This is a very serious thing."
These candidates, united by a reckless disregard for truth and responsible public rhetoric during a public health emergency, should be ashamed of their galactically irresponsible remarks. The Trump administration has not "wiped out" or "defunded" the CDC or the National Institutes for Health. Further, there are several experts figuring out "what the hell" to do.
According to the Associated Press, funding has increased for both agencies during the Trump administration, and the experts in charge have earned praise from across the political spectrum: Dr. Anne Schuchat, the CDC's principal deputy director, is so good Hollywood based a movie on her work, and Dr. Anthony Fauci, the NIH's infectious disease head, has advised six presidents.
It is outrageous that leading Democrats would so brazenly lie to the public about the American government's response. But who will hold them accountable? Let's check in with our national newspaper of record, The New York Times:
"Let's call it Trumpvirus," blared a headline atop a column written by Gail Collins, one of the paper's most well-known writers. Columnist Paul Krugman, also using the "Trumpvirus" label, excitedly tweeted "Dow 25,000!" as the stock market tanked.
Other corners of the American left, ever disdainful of organized religion, pounded Vice President Mike Pence, who Trump tasked with leading the government's response. As governor of Indiana, Pence once said he wanted to pray about a controversial needle exchange program in response to an outbreak of HIV/AIDS in his state. And a photo of his coronavirus task force with heads bowed in prayer earned widespread scorn, with one New York Times Magazine contributor tweeting that America is "so screwed."
I wonder: Do the liberals hammering Pence have the same thoughts about Democratic presidential candidates attending Bloody Sunday church services in Selma this past weekend?
As if we needed another reminder, Donald Trump has broken these people. Absolutely broken them. A virus jumps from an animal to a human halfway around the world and the liberal intelligentsia tries to name it after the American president, cheerleads a decline in the retirement fortunes of millions of Americans and crusades against basic religious practices.
There is no high-minded, we-are-all-in-this-together alternative to Trump. There is no paragon of honesty or virtue or competence waiting to turn the American presidency into a new season of "The West Wing." There is just a disgustingly disloyal opposition, whose happiest recent days were brought on by a global pandemic.
But even as his opposition grows more irresponsible, Trump is not absolved of the need for an accurate, clear and sober public message. He should not minimize the risk or engage in his usual hyperbole. This is where the rubber hits the road on public trust, and Trump needs to get it exactly right or face extreme political damage.
His best course is to simply be calm and honest: More people will get this virus, some will die, and washing your hands is a good way to stay healthy. The administration should give routine updates on progress toward a vaccine, mortality rates and travel advice.
Scott Jennings is a Republican adviser, CNN contributor, and partner at RunSwitch Public Relations. Contact him at Scott@RunSwitchPR.com or on Twitter @ScottJenningsKY.
Scott Jennings
Guest columnist

Can our rural roads be saved?

Información de publicación: Coshocton Tribune ; Coshocton, Ohio [Coshocton, Ohio]. 08 Mar 2020: A.7.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/can-our-rural-roads-be-saved/docview/2373480596/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Can+our+rural+roads+be+saved%3F&amp;author=&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.7&amp;date=2020-03-08&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Coshocton+Tribune&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Amidwestnews1_

Texto completo: The recent New York Times article "The Struggle to Mend America's Rural Roads" used Wisconsin as a microcosm for the infrastructure crisis that either directly or indirectly affects all Americans.
Personally, I'm tickled with the job the county road department does with my own stretch of country road. But for people in many states and localities, broken axles, wrecked suspension systems, busted tires, emergency road closings and unpredictable weight limits for aging bridges are an ever-looming danger. Shoppers, commuters, tourists, farmers and truckers hauling the nation's food supply are all at the mercy of substandard rural roads.
The normal life span of an asphalt road is 30 years, but many rural roads have been in service for more than 75 years.
Unfortunately, road construction and maintenance do not come cheap. Reconstructing a mile of road costs $300,000; even chip sealing (a kind of short-term patching) costs $17,000 a mile. Some officeholders are better at keeping costs down than others.
All federal, state and local agencies must make hard decisions about finite resources, but some places are less ashamed of their stinginess than others.
Many urbanites – unable to see past their subways and other forms of mass transit – demonstrate a dismaying lack of empathy for fellow Americans who live in "flyover country." ("I didn't force them to live in the boonies.)
To be sure, open-minded city-dwellers can visit the hinterlands and really "click" with the locals and their needs. Their hearts are in the right place. (Or maybe their hearts have shifted to the lower intestine region after hitting one bump too many.)
But even the most sympathetic visitors know that whatever state or federal funding might materialize, the answer must start with the people directly affected. And locals can be reluctant to disrupt the status quo by opening their wallets wider. As John Denver sang, "Country roads, take me home – unless there's a big tax bill waiting in the mailbox!"
Still, I hope the Times article will reignite a long-stalled national discussion of the seen and unseen costs of deteriorating infrastructure. People from all regions, all income levels, all political persuasions must put their petty differences aside, roll up their sleeves and brainstorm solutions.
As Prof. Emmett Brown from "Back to the Future" might have said, "Bipartisanship? Where we're going, we don't need bipartisanship! KA-THUMP KA-THUMP CRASH! AIIIIEEEEE!"
Danny welcomes email responses at tyreetyrades@aol.com and visits to his Facebook fan page "Tyree's Tyrades." Danny's weekly column is distributed exclusively by Cagle Cartoons Inc. newspaper syndicate.

Coronavirus fears make 2011's 'Contagion' suddenly relevant

Información de publicación: Detroit Free Press ; Detroit, Mich. [Detroit, Mich]. 08 Mar 2020: E.2.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/coronavirus-fears-make-2011s-contagion-suddenly/docview/2373480583/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Coronavirus+fears+make+2011%27s+%27Contagion%27+suddenly+relevant&amp;author=&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=E.2&amp;date=2020-03-08&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Detroit+Free+Press&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Amidwestnews1_

Texto completo: The 2011 movie "Contagion" does something in its first few minutes that public health officials are still trying to accomplish.
It makes the advice to wash your hands often seem as urgent as that inevitable moment in horror films where the viewers want to yell at the screen, "Get out of the house ... now!"
Life in 2020 is increasingly a nervous waiting game for coronavirus updates. What's the latest headline? Which events have been canceled? How many states have declared an emergency?
This week, even James Bond was put on hold. The release of the 007 movie "No Time To Die" was moved from April to November over worries about theater closings in Italy, South Korea, China and Japan — countries hit hard by COVID-19, the abbreviated name for the virus.
There is a lot of worry happening, along with some panicked stockpiling of toilet paper. So why would anyone want to watch "Contagion," which has climbed the charts faster than a Lizzo single?
Because, in the big picture, it's worth seeing. Sure, it will freak you out. But its message on the need for precautions is beyond powerful.
"Contagion," a well-crafted drama that until recently was relatively obscure, has become a hot rental at online sites like Amazon Prime and iTunes.
Why? As director Barry Jenkins ("Moonlight") told the New York Times, ""I was really curious to see how well it would line up to what is happening right now. It was shocking. It felt like I was watching a documentary that has all these movie stars playing real people."
Nowhere is that more evident than in a scene where CNN's Dr. Sanjay Gupta — yes, the real guy did a cameo — is interviewing a CDC expert played by Laurence Fishburne.
"Our best defense has been social distancing, no handshaking, staying home when you're sick, washing your hands frequently," says Fishburne.
That sounds exactly like a clip from any and every cable news channel.
Art imitates life so closely in such sequences that you may begin to wonder whether the rest of the movie will come true. And that's a frightening prospect because the screenplay deals with catastrophic loss.
But "Contagion" is fictional. The coronavirus is not the same as the MEV-1 virus imagined by the movie.
In real life, COVID-19, first detected in Wuhan, China, in December, has resulted globally in nearly 100,000 cases and more than 3,300 deaths.
In the film, Gwyneth Paltrow's character brings the MEV-1 virus to Minneapolis after a business trip to Hong Kong, Roughly a month into the made-up time line, the death toll is 2.5 million in America alone.
The COVID-19 death rate has been estimated as 3.4%. The imaginary MEV-1 virus kills more like 20% of those infected.
Clearly, "Contagion" is a worst-case scenario with an all-star cast.
It's a great ensemble. Matt Damon portrays an everyman dad struggling to hold things together for his teenage daughter. Laurence Fishburne, Kate Winslet and Marion Cotillard play dedicated public health experts. Jude Law is intense and reckless as a conspiracy-chasing blogger, while Jennifer Ehle is equally risk-taking, but in a heroic way, as a CDC scientist racing to find a vaccine.
Oh, and — spoiler alert! — Paltrow, as Damon's wife, dies almost immediately after returning home as a result of the lightning-fast progression of the disease.
Soderbergh's 9-year-old movie is a master class in creating suspense out of rather complex science.
Early on, Paltrow's character sits in a Chicago airport bar and coughs occasionally as she waits for a delayed flight. The camera pans to the bowl of nuts that she's been eating from, then to the credit card she hands to the bartender, then to the machine where the card is swiped.
This is a thriller where the danger lies not in criminals or maniacs, but the human touch.
As clues pop up in Hong Kong, London, and Tokyo that a pandemic is emerging, it becomes clear that the villainous germs are outpacing the knowledge of experts. Fishburne and his CDC team must scramble to identify and contain the virus. They track clusters of infections at health clubs and elementary schools and, in Winslet's case, travel to a hot zone. As a result of what they learn, the process starts of creating a vaccine in time to save literally millions of lives. Along the way, they sometimes put their own lives in jeopardy (a nice way of saying that Paltrow isn't the only shocking casualty).
Meanwhile, rumors spread through Law's Truth Serum Now blog that the virus is actually a military or industrial weapon. Law touts a natural cure, forsythia, and brags about having 12 million unique visitors. One of the movie's more gratifying scenes comes when a veteran scientist played by Elliott Gould blasts Law's careless journalistic standards. "Blogging is not writing," barks Gould. "It's graffiti with punctuation."
"Contagion" floats many plot twists that echo with what is known about COVID-19, including tying the origin of the fictional virus to bats and pigs. Recently in real life, China banned the wildlife trade over suspicions that exotic animals infected humans.
In the movie, hospitals are flooded with patients and a National Guard armory is turned into a vast triage center for bed-ridden patients. In real-world Wuhan, China, where COVID-19 was first detected, two hospitals were built to deal with the sick in a little more than a week's time.
Yet "Contagion" takes things to awful extremes. By the time it's over, quarantines are in place is some cities. Rioting and looting have cleared out stores. The president is off somewhere at an undisclosed location. Ultimately, 26 million people in the United States die, and some of them are buried by necessity in mass graves.
Don't mistake "Contagion" for a guidebook. It's just a creative exercise. But pay attention to the movie's cautionary lessons. Learn what precautions and preparations you should be taking. Seek information from legitimate sources and avoid unproven theories and scams that litter social media.
This is serious stuff. If we are able to look back someday and conclude that the United States was over-prepared for the coronavirus outbreak — that the impact wasn't as bad as we feared — well, that would be a blessing.
But we're not through this yet, so keep listening to scientists, doctors and other medical experts.
You don't have to sit through "Contagion" to understand all of this. But it's one heck of a reminder to wash your hands.

Can you hire hit man on dark web? Experts who have studied these sites say they are scams

Autor: Popper, Nathaniel. 

Información de publicación: Orlando Sentinel ; Orlando, Fla. [Orlando, Fla]. 08 Mar 2020: A.25.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/can-you-hire-hit-man-on-dark-web-experts-who-have/docview/2373480533/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Can+you+hire+hit+man+on+dark+web%3F+Experts+who+have+studied+these+sites+say+they+are+scams&amp;author=Popper%2C+Nathaniel&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.25&amp;date=2020-03-08&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Orlando+Sentinel&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Asoutheastnews_

Texto completo: SAN FRANCISCO - On a website called Azerbaijani Eagles, you can commission a murder for $5,000. The site Slayers Hitmen provides more options, with a beating going for $2,000. Death by torture costs $50,000.
But don't expect someone to get the job done. Experts and law enforcers who have studied these sites - almost all of them on the so-called dark web or dark net - say they are scams. There has not been a known murder attributed to any of them.
That doesn't mean the sites aren't involved in a very dark trade. They have become catch points for real people who are looking to pay to have someone killed. And a number of men and women are sitting in jail after paying one of these sites - and getting caught by police.
In one of the most recent cases to make its way through the courts, a nurse from Illinois was sentenced to 12 years in prison after pleading guilty to sending $12,000 in bitcoin to the site Sicilian Hitmen International Network. She had hoped to have the wife of her boyfriend killed.
Twenty-four hit-man-for-hire sites are the subject of an academic paper that was shared in advance with The New York Times by Michigan State University professor Tom Holt and student Ariel Roddy.
The paper is the first academic effort to illuminate what has been a subject of endless intrigue. For years, the potential anonymity granted by the internet has fed predictions that there would be marketplaces for death and assassination.
But it was the emergence of the dark web over the past decade or so that allowed hitman sites to proliferate. Unlike most sites on the traditional internet, dark-web sites use technology that allows both sides of an online interaction to hide their identity and location, from each other and law enforcement.
"It's a fantastic opportunity to defraud people because you give them just enough sense of danger," said Emily Wilson, head of research at Terbium Labs, a security company focused on the dark net. "What are you going to do if they don't go through with it?"
When the first hit-man sites were discovered, an assumption was that the dark web was crawling with legitimate assassins waiting to kill on command.
Promotional material posted to the mainstream internet played on that assumption. One site, which provides readers with a link to the dark net address of the 18th Street Gang, holds itself out as a "guide to real hit men, facts and stories." The site claims that people who say hit-man sites are scams are just trying to discourage people from seeking them out.
"Most customers order from reliable hit men sites that have been proven as legitimate," the site says.
On many of the sites examined by the team at Michigan State, considerable effort was expended trying to prove their legitimacy so customers would feel comfortable making a payment in Bitcoin, the digital currency. Hit men are not the sort of thing you pay for with a credit card.
The site 18th Street Mafia includes a page with links to news stories about real killings it says it helped commit. None of the articles, however, indicate that the site, or even a hit man, was responsible.
The site says: "We can provide video proof of our services, with time stamps. Again, such proof is not possible for fake services."
The 18th Street Mafia did not respond to requests for comment.
The representative for another site, Darkmamba, said in an email that proving its legitimacy had been difficult because "the point of our services and many other, including underground criminal forums, is to indeed complete the job without leaving anything that could get traced back to us."
The most prolific research on these sites has been conducted by Chris Monteiro, a systems administrator in London who has pursued his investigations as a morbid passion project on top of his regular job.
Monteiro hacked into one of the sites created by the most notorious purveyor of assassination sites, a figure going by the name Yura.
After breaking into the Besa Mafia site and a few others, Monteiro found information about 283 people who had paid for hit-man services. He also found messages suggesting that the operators had little intention of going through with the killings.
"I need you to help me do some videos to prove the Besa Mafia legit, but WITHOUT killing anyone," the operator wrote in one email, trying to get a contractor to produce lifelike videos. "I am not a murderer and I don't want anyone be murdered."
Law enforcement agencies around the world have been hesitant to collaborate with Monteiro or use his evidence because of the way he acquired it. But Monteiro has worked with media organizations, including Wired and 48 Hours, which have passed his information to law enforcement officials, eventually leading to the arrests of people who paid the sites to connect them with a hit man.
Monteiro has identified nine cases in which people he exposed were arrested in connection with commissioning hits. In one of the most gruesome cases, a man in Minnesota was arrested after he was found to have killed his wife himself when the hit man he had commissioned on the Besa Mafia website for about $6,000 in bitcoin did not come through.
A police investigator in Russia is believed to have been killed by two teenagers who were hired by a drug trafficker on the dark net. An investigation by the BBC found that the killing had been commissioned on one of the broad marketplaces on the dark net where drugs and stolen credit cards are sold.
But there has still not been a killing commissioned on one of the dedicated hit-man-for-hire sites.
"Why would you set up a dedicated site online when you know absolutely that law enforcement are going to be flooding that site trying to find you?" Wilson said. "You are making yourself too big of a target."
Still, the sites have continued to proliferate. A few months ago, a middle-age executive in Singapore was sent to jail for five years after paying the Camorra Hitman site to kill the boyfriend of his young ex-lover in a staged car accident that, not surprisingly, didn't happen.
Wilson, of Terbium Labs, said these sites took attention from the real crime being committed on the dark net, such as the drug markets and the sites selling the sensitive personal information of millions of Americans.
"There is actual crime, but we are too busy talking about some guy who wants to kill his ex-girlfriend's new boyfriend," she said.
Caption: PHOTO: A collection of online stores offer murder for pay, but researchers say they are scams.
The New York Times

Can our rural roads be saved?

Author Michael Koryta takes on new identity

Autor: JENNY PORTER TILLEY. 

Información de publicación: Indianapolis Star ; Indianapolis, Ind. [Indianapolis, Ind]. 08 Mar 2020: E.1.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/author-michael-koryta-takes-on-new-identity/docview/2373480505/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Author+Michael+Koryta+takes+on+new+identity&amp;author=JENNY+PORTER+TILLEY&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=E.1&amp;date=2020-03-08&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Indianapolis+Star&amp;issn=1930-2533&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Amidwestnews1_

Texto completo: Who is Scott Carson?
In the jacket of his book "The Chill," which came out last month, it's revealed that it's actually a pen name for a best-selling author in New England.
Carson's ties are a little closer to home, though. He's actually Indiana University alumnus Michael Koryta.
"The Chill" was inspired by an April 2016 story in the New York Times with the headline "(New York Mayor Bill) DeBlasio postpones work on crucial water tunnel." The story mentions a 2002 meeting during previous Mayor Michael Bloomberg's first few weeks in the position, when officials discussed emergency preparedness for various disaster scenarios — terrorist attacks and hurricanes, for example.
With century-old tunnels carrying billions of gallons of water into the city, the possibility of their collapse was another very real threat. Koryta said he hopes his story will not only entertain readers, but also help them understand what it means to lose funding to repair our country's infrastructure.
"It really is terrifying," he said. "It reminds me of the loss of community news. It's the sort of thing that it's very easy for a community or country to overlook. At some point, someone will be writing about these dams — and it'll either be front page news of a tragedy, or it'll be a small story inside about someone allocating a budget to fix it."
The former Herald-Times reporter said the New York Times story was an example of how reporters on less "sexy" beats cover crucial topics that often don't get much attention. "The only way that this book came into existence was because a reporter on a municipal beat did a great story that I then saw," Koryta said. "But without that article, there's no book."
Despite its roots in municipal planning, "The Chill" is at its heart a ghost story, so of course, there are ghosts. They include workers who died building water tunnels; families from the historic towns drowned in favor of providing water to the big city; and current-day characters who become ghosts as the story progresses. Interactions between the living and the dead — and progress and disaster — turn a cautionary tale about government spending into true horror.
One character in the book is a woman who was raised in the culture of a town that was claimed by eminent domain to build a reservoir for New York City water. As a girl, she brought the long-dead town to life through her sketchbook.
Koryta enlisted the help of 17-year-old Edgewood High School junior April Strawn to include the sketches in the back cover of the novel. "She's just a stunningly talented artist," he said — too talented, in fact. "I had to ask her to bring her talent down a notch, to make it look like an a child had drawn it."
The result is a spread of rough sketches that help bring the story of the water to life. Strawn's work is paired with haunting archival photos Koryta found in the New York Public Library, documenting a time when villages that had been there for hundreds of years were evacuated.
With the help of his alter-ego, Koryta answered some questions about his new project and the future of Scott Carson.
Q: Why did you decide to take up a pseudonym?
A: Practical and impractical reasons. On the latter, I'd always loved the idea of having a pseudonym and a second writer identity. Seems like fun, and provides some new perspective and new energy. On the former, the practical consideration, it has been nearly a decade since I last wrote a supernatural story, and it made sense to try to provide some brand clarity to the booksellers, where Carson will write only supernatural stories, and Koryta will stay out of his way. I've always had a dream of having a name that strangers can pronounce and spell, too. In a word-of-mouth business, it seems beneficial!
Q: What are some of your favorite pseudonyms by other authors?
A: Always a fan of Joe Hill, who is Stephen King's son but was determined to prove that he could publish without the help of the last name. People question the reality of that story, but I worked with an editor who passed on Joe Hill's first book, and I assure you he didn't know that Hill was King's son at that time. I liked what John Banville did, with Benjamin Black handling his genre side and John remaining in the literary pool. And I'm a big fan of this guy named Mark Twain.
Q: How does Scott Carson differ from your true self, as an author? What makes his writing separate?
A: Sadly, I haven't seen Scott come up with a unique style. His work reminds me of "So Cold the River," "The Cypress House," and "The Ridge." (A comparison that was made in a Publisher's Weekly review, which made me chuckle.) But I'm leaving Scott on the dark side, so we will see what happens to him as time goes by. I mean, he's from New England. Any good Colts fan understands that is morally perilous country, a land that corrupts the soul. I worry for Scott, spending so much time in a place like that.
Q: To follow up the previous question, how do you decide whether something is a Scott Carson book vs. a Michael Koryta book?
A: Anything with the supernatural or a more speculative/magical element will be left in Scott's hands. Koryta is working on a book that features the Blackwell family of "Those Who Wish Me Dead" and "If She Wakes." He's underwater at the moment, so hopefully Scott is being productive.
Q: If Scott Carson were an actual person, what do you image he'd be like? Look like? Do for fun? Where would he live? What does he wear?
A: What do you mean "if" he were an actual person? I know the guy! He's a bit of a homebody, not very social. Lives in a place where the sun goes down early and work is done in the dark. It's a chilly place. He has a fondness for black hoodies, particularly one adorned with movie spoilers. He likes a good whiskey. He's big on long walks with his dog in the cold. The dog is his first editor, and seems often unimpressed by the ideas that Scott offers on those walks.
Q: What are Scott's plans for the future?
A: Well, he's under contract to deliver more books, so I hope he is hard at work. We should be hearing from him again sometime in the next two years.
Contact Jenny Porter Tilley at 812-331-4377, jtilley@heraldt.com or follow @jennylynne on Twitter.

Dems face a split party following Super Tuesday

Información de publicación: Reno Gazette - Journal ; Reno, Nev. [Reno, Nev]. 08 Mar 2020: D.5.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/dems-face-split-party-following-super-tuesday/docview/2373480467/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Dems+face+a+split+party+following+Super+Tuesday&amp;author=&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.5&amp;date=2020-03-08&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Reno+Gazette+-+Journal&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Awestnews_

Texto completo: Super Tuesday has come and gone. A total of 1,357 delegates (34% of the total) were allocated to various candidates on March 3. While most of the delegates from the Super Tuesday are still in the process of being allocated, there are clear trends that give us a good idea of where things are headed in the Democrat nomination contest.
Swing state problem: Bernie has had strong performances in New Hampshire, Iowa, Nevada, Colorado and Minnesota. They are all swing states in the general election. 12% of Bernie supporters in 2016 voted for Trump in the general election (source: NPR). Expect that number to be higher this time if Bernie is not the nominee.
Racial divide: Blacks are going strong for Biden; Hispanics are going strong for Bernie. In a two-man race, this is an interesting dynamic to watch. The Hispanic factor could easily swing Nevada red if Bernie is not the Democrat nominee.
Biden's gaffes get worse: During his Super Tuesday victory speech, he confused his wife for his sister. A day before, he called it "Super Thursday" before stopping himself. He called Chris Wallace "Chuck" (as in Todd). During the debate he claimed 150 million American lives (about half of the total population) were lost to gun violence since 2007. He botched the Declaration of Independence during a rally in Texas with, "All men and women created ... by the — you know — you know the thing." A single miss is not an issue. Taken collectively, this pattern of miscues is disquieting. In my column "Bob Mueller's last act has come and gone" (Aug. 7), I wrote about the once-great war hero Bob Mueller's disappointing testimony where he looked totally lost. Much like Mueller, Joe Biden, once a dominant figure in American politics, appears to be headed in the wrong direction cognitively at a crucial time.
More progressive weapons backfire: Progressive activists constantly entered Trump rallies in the lead-up to the 2016 election. While I fully recognize one's rights to peaceful protests, entering another person's event to disrupt proceedings clearly crosses the line. That weapon has now turned against the Democrats. Amy Klobuchar had to cancel a rally when protestors stormed the stage. Joe Biden's victory speech was interrupted by protestors nearly endangering the former vice president's physical safety. Bernie's rally in Carson City was interrupted by protestors last month.
Networks deceive: Networks kept "calling" the race and putting a check mark next to the candidate like it is the general election. Somehow, they ignored the fact that unlike the general election, where it is winner-take-all, the Democratic primary allocates delegates proportionally. Take Texas as an example. At last check, Biden had bagged 81 delegates and Bernie had won 72 delegates. Yet the networks declared Biden a "winner" a few hours after the polls closed.
One final point: Just before the South Carolina primary, fresh off a massive win in Nevada, Bernie Sanders appeared to have a clear path to the Democrat party nomination. The New York Times interviewed 93 unelected "superdelegates." According to The Times, they were committed to stopping Bernie Sanders even if it meant intraparty damage. This adds fuel to the Bernie Bros.' perception they are being cheated.
Following Biden's victory in South Carolina and on the eve of Super Tuesday, Klobuchar, Buttigieg and O'Rourke all endorsed Biden. The day after Super Tuesday, Bloomberg dropped out and endorsed Biden. The timing of these endorsements will sure come across to Bernie supporters as an organized attempt by the party to stop Bernie. If Bernie does not win the nomination, these endorsements will come back to haunt the Democrats in the general election and for years to come.
Sam Kumar is the former chairman of the Washoe County Republican Party.
From the Right
Sam Kumar
Guest columnist

Opportunities for teen success at Shreve Memorial Library

Información de publicación: The Times ; Shreveport, La. [Shreveport, La]. 08 Mar 2020: A.2.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/opportunities-teen-success-at-shreve-memorial/docview/2373480024/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Opportunities+for+teen+success+at+Shreve+Memorial+Library&amp;author=&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.2&amp;date=2020-03-08&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Times&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Asouthcentralnews_

Texto completo: Throughout the month, Shreve Memorial Library is celebrating Youth Art Month (YAM) and giving teens a chance to develop visual arts skills to use after high school.
Libraries offer tons of resources to help teens succeed in school and prepare for life after graduation. Shreve Memorial Library is no different. The library provides homework help, test preparation, creative outlets, and even job opportunities for teens.
Teens and children of all ages can get homework assistance through programs like the North Shreveport Branch's Homework Club. The Homework Club meets on Monday evenings at 4 p.m. and offers a fun place to work on homework assignments, study for a test, and get peer tutoring. In essence, the Homework Club is kids helping kids to make the grade.
Teens looking to further their educations can also prep for big tests like the ACT or SAT with help from the library. Online resources such as Homework Louisiana and Learning Express provide practice tests and study resources for taking the ACT, SAT, AP tests, and more. In addition, the Main (Downtown) Branch of Shreve Memorial Library will host an ACT Practice Test free of charge on Saturday, March 28 from 9:30 a.m. to 12:30 p.m. Teens can practice taking the ACT in a simulated testing facility. The practice tests last three hours and features each of the four tests – English, Math, Reading and Science – that appear on the actual ACT. Teens can register for the test at bit.ly/2SYbjM1.
Throughout the month, Shreve Memorial Library is celebrating Youth Art Month (YAM) and giving teens a chance to develop visual arts skills to use after high school. Teens can learn to paint, draw, and even become a sculptor following in the footsteps of great artists such as Henri Matisse, Michelangelo, Vincent Van Gogh and Gianlorenzo Bernini. Skills learned in these hands-on workshops can be applied to a variety of career fields.
And did I mention that Shreve Memorial Library also provides job opportunities for teens? Now through March 18, teens age 16+ can apply for a paid summer internship at the library. What better way to get real world life experience than with a summer job? To apply, teens must be at least 16 years of age by March 18, have a 2.0 GPA, and be enrolled in high school.
At Shreve Memorial Library, we believe that everyone should be able to dream, discover and do. For more information about teen opportunities at Shreve Memorial Library and to apply for a summer internship, visit www.shreve-lib.org.
What's New at the Library Lady Clementine by Marie Benedict (fiction)
From Marie Benedict, the New York Times bestselling author of The Only Woman in the Room, an incredible novel that focuses on one of the people who had the most influence during World War I and World War II: Clementine Churchill. In 1909, Clementine steps off a train with her new husband, Winston. An angry woman emerges from the crowd to attack, shoving him in the direction of an oncoming train. Just before he stumbles, Clementine grabs him by his suit jacket. This will not be the last time Clementine Churchill will save her husband. Lady Clementine is the ferocious story of the ambitious woman beside Winston Churchill, the story of a partner who did not flinch through the sweeping darkness of war, and who would not surrender either to expectations or to enemies.
When You See Me by Lisa Gardner (fiction)
FBI Special Agent Kimberly Quincy and Sergeant Detective D.D. Warren have built a task force to follow the digital bread crumbs left behind by deceased serial kidnapper Jacob Ness. When a disturbing piece of evidence is discovered in the hills of Georgia, they bring Flora Dane and true-crime savant Keith Edgar to a small town where something seems to be deeply wrong. What at first looks like a Gothic eeriness soon hardens into something much more sinister... and they discover that for all the evil Jacob committed while alive, his worst secret is still to be revealed. Quincy and D.D. must summon their considerable skills and experience to crack the most disturbing case of their careers – and Flora must face her own past directly in the hope of saving others.
We Are the Nerds by Christine Lagorio-Chafkin (non-fiction)
Reddit hails itself as "the front page of the Internet." It's the third most-visited website in the United States – and yet, millions of Americans have no idea what it is. We Are the Nerds is an engrossing look deep inside this captivating, maddening enterprise, whose army of obsessed users have been credited with everything from solving cold case crimes and spurring tens of millions of dollars in charitable donations to seeding alt-right fury and landing Donald Trump in the White House. We Are the Nerds is a gripping start-up narrative: the story of how Reddit's founders, Steve Huffman and Alexis Ohanian, rose up from their suburban childhoods to become millionaires and create an icon of the digital age – before seeing the site engulfed in controversies and nearly losing control of it for good. Based on Christine Lagorio-Chafkin's exclusive access to founders Ohanian and Huffman, We Are the Nerds is also a compelling exploration of the way we all communicate today – and how we got here. Reddit and its users have become a mirror of the Internet: it has dingy corners, shiny memes, malicious trolls, and a sometimes heart-melting ability to connect people across cultures, oceans, and ideological divides.
Samantha Bonnette is marketing & development manager at Shreve Memorial Library.

Eight ways to save for your summer vacation

Autor: Cruze, Rachel. 

Información de publicación: News Journal ; Mansfield, Ohio [Mansfield, Ohio]. 08 Mar 2020: A.2.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/eight-ways-save-your-summer-vacation/docview/2373479905/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Eight+ways+to+save+for+your+summer+vacation&amp;author=Cruze%2C+Rachel&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.2&amp;date=2020-03-08&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=News+Journal&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Amidwestnews1_

Texto completo: Have you started planning your summer vacation yet? It'll be sipping-lemonade-by-the-pool season before you know it. I love vacations, but here's what I don't love: Nearly 40 percent of millennials are willing to go into debt for their trips.
Coming back home to credit card bills makes the end of a vacation miserable. I don't want that to be your story. If you start saving up now, you'll be in great shape when it's time to pack your bags.
Here are eight ways to save up and pay for your vacation with your own money:
1. Give your budget a refresh. If it's been a while since you looked at where your money is really going each month, I bet you'll find some areas where you can cut back in a matter of minutes. Then, you can put that cash toward your vacation fund.
2. Brew your own coffee at home. I get it. Fancy coffee with a designer label makes me feel special, too. But if you put that $25 a week into a vacation fund for a while, you'll add a couple hundred bucks or more to your travel budget.
3. Pack your lunch. Peanut butter and jelly today means piña coladas all day on the beach this summer.
4. Order water at restaurants. If you go out to eat, give up extras like soda, appetizers, and alcohol.
5. Save on groceries by shopping generic or at Aldi. Everyone I know swears their grocery bill was slashed in half simply by switching to shopping at Aldi. If you don't have one near you, you can save money buying store brand or generic brand items.
6. Sell your kids' clothes at consignment stores. I'm a huge fan of this! I also love shopping consignment to save money.
7. Sell stuff online through places like Facebook Marketplace. You know there's stuff lying around the house, in the garage, or in your closet that you don't use anymore. Put it to good use by selling it, and put that money toward your vacation!
8. Cancel any unused subscriptions. When's the last time you really watched a show on HBO, or used any of the makeup samples from your Birchbox? I'm not hating on subscription services, but if you don't use them, that's money leaving your bank account each month you could be saving.
Once you try these money-saving tips, you might just make them a habit. Then, you'll be ahead of the game when it's vacation time next year. My free Vacation Budget Worksheet makes it super easy to plan for all your expenses.
Things always cost more than you expect. But this worksheet will help you plan for everything — even the unexpected stuff.
As a No.1 New York Times best-selling author, host of The Rachel Cruze Show, and The Rachel Cruze Show podcast, Rachel helps people learn the proper ways to handle money and stay out of debt. She's authored three best-selling books. You can follow Cruze at rachelcruze.com.

Worst-case scenario would call for drastic measures School closings? Canceled events? It's all possible. CORONAVIRUS IN CONNECTICUT

Autor: Putterman, Alex. 

Información de publicación: Hartford Courant ; Hartford, Conn. [Hartford, Conn]. 08 Mar 2020: A.6.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/worst-case-scenario-would-call-drastic-measures/docview/2373478998/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Worst-case+scenario+would+call+for+drastic+measures+School+closings%3F+Canceled+events%3F+It%27s+all+possible.+CORONAVIRUS+IN+CONNECTICUT&amp;author=Putterman%2C+Alex&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.6&amp;date=2020-03-08&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Hartford+Courant&amp;issn=1047-4153&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anortheastnews1_

Texto completo: As of now, doctors and public health officials have limited tools to combat COVID-19, the new strain of coronavirus that has quickly spread across the world.
There is no vaccine. There is no antiviral treatment. There is only preventing the spread through "social distancing," a term that encompasses everything from closing schools to shutting down parks and mass transit.
"When we are dealing with an epidemic, we reach in the tool box and pull out a vaccine," state epidemiologist Matthew Cartter said. "But [with coronavirus], we don't have that."
In a worst-case scenario, the implications for Connecticut could be far-reaching. Public schools could close, colleges could shut down, public places could be deserted, the upcoming presidential primary could be affected.
Cartter was clear Friday that Connecticut does not yet need drastic measures. No one knows exactly how quickly COVID-19 will move or how many people will become sick, though experts say most patients will self-recover, as they would after the flu. With only two confirmed cases linked to the state, Connecticut has not been hit as hard as others.
But given the possibility of large-scale outbreak and the lack of treatment options, wide closures could eventually become necessary, as officials seek to slow the spread enough to treat severe cases.
"Most of us do not remember the kind of control measures that are going to be needed to keep hospitals open, to keep taking care of the most seriously ill," Cartter said, referencing the 1918-19 influenza pandemic.
For the state to impose mass closures, Gov. Ned Lamont would have to declare a civil preparedness emergency, which would give him broad powers over public institutions. Brenda Bergeron, principal attorney for the Division of Emergency Management and Homeland Security, said Lamont's decision to take that step will depend on conversations with his unified command.
"The governor's office has the state agencies consider what they might need to waive or modify," Bergeron said, "and if there's a need for that, that's one of the reasons he might declare an emergency."
So far, governors in California, Washington, Florida and Maryland have declared states of emergency in response to COVID-19.
Across the world, regions with significant COVID-19 outbreaks have begun to take dramatic precautions. As of Tuesday, 22 countries on three continents had closed schools because of the virus, according to the United Nations, resulting in almost 300 million students left at home. In Italy, all professional soccer games will be played without any fans in attendance for the next month. Disneyland parks in Shanghai and Tokyo have been closed temporarily.
Public officials in the United States have begun to weigh similarly strong responses. One public school district in Washington state has suspended classes for up to two weeks, and the University of Washington said Friday that it would cancel in-person classes and have students take courses and finals remotely while the Seattle area grapples with a growing outbreak. If the virus becomes more widespread, other colleges around the country could follow.
Over the last few days, a growing number of universities have mobilized emergency planning teams to envision what a shutdown would look like, especially if students bring the virus back with them from spring break, which started Friday on many campuses.
Already, some students have been warned that they should be prepared to learn online, as many students studying abroad in Europe and Asia have been forced to do.
On Friday, organizers canceled the South by Southwest festival in Austin, Texas, citing coronavirus. Closures and cancellations are likely to continue in coming weeks and months, as authorities consider even more dramatic responses, such as the cancellation of the Summer Olympics in Japan.
In Connecticut, the state Department of Education says it continues to coordinate with local school districts as they weigh potential responses. Until the state declares a civil preparedness emergency, decisions on school cancellations continue to fall to individual districts.
Writing in the New York Times, University of Michigan medical historian Howard Markel argued that school districts should err toward closing, citing his study on the 1918-19 flu pandemic.
"School closing turned out to be one of the most effective firewalls against the spread of the pandemic," he wrote. "Cities that acted fast, for lengthy periods of time, and included school closing and at least one other [non-pharmaceutical intervention] in their responses saw the lowest death rates."
Most states, including Connecticut, continue to hold widely attended events, such as the UConn men's basketball game in Storrs on Thursday night that drew more than 10,000 fans.
Asked whether those events pose danger, health officials said risk is limited as long as there is no community transmission - i.e. no residents are being infected here in Connecticut.
Travel restrictions could also expand along with the spread of the virus. Currently, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention have travel advisories of varying severity for five countries: China, Iran, Italy, South Korea and Japan, as well as Hong Kong.
Many colleges, including in Connecticut, have canceled school-related travel. UConn has urged students to cancel all non-essential international trips, including on spring break.
"The coronavirus situation continues to rapidly evolve; because of this, travel restrictions and guidance may also continue to change very quickly," UConn said in a statement.

3 steps to communicate your value to customers

Información de publicación: Detroit Free Press ; Detroit, Mich. [Detroit, Mich]. 08 Mar 2020: B.4.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/3-steps-communicate-your-value-customers/docview/2373478962/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=3+steps+to+communicate+your+value+to+customers&amp;author=&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=B.4&amp;date=2020-03-08&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Detroit+Free+Press&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Amidwestnews1_

Texto completo: As business leaders, we're often faced with the challenge of explaining what we do. It could be in a casual setting like a dinner party, or a more formal sales presentation to that big new potential account. The problem is, most of us get it all wrong.
We tend to explain what we do in the context of our product or service. We tell people we manufacture industrial drill presses, or sell variable life insurance, or perform massage therapy. While factually accurate, there is a far better way to communicate your value proposition.
Communicating the transformation you create for customers, instead of the mechanics of how you do it, will help people better understand the value you provide. To do so, try to craft your message such that it addresses these three customer promises:
1. After working with me, customers will have no more _______________.
2. After working with me, customer will have a good deal more ___________.
3. After working with me, customers will have less ________________.
No more. More. And less.
If you can explain how you impact customers' lives across these three aspects, you'll create a powerful and emotionally charged connection point.
Instead of saying that you are a corporate travel agency, why not say that your travel services eliminate wasted travel costs and surprises (No. 1), providing customers a lot more peace of mind (No. 2) while having wasted far less time (No. 3)?
Instead of saying you run a cybersecurity business, try saying that you help clients eliminate threats of all types (No. 1), allowing them to devote more resources to serving their customers (No. 2) while having a lot less anxiety and fear over an inevitable cyber-attack (No. 3).
Of course, you can switch up the order and personalize to your style and needs. The point is, getting clear how you specifically help customers eliminate something (No. 1), get more of something (No. 2), and get less of something (No. 3), will dramatically boost the efficacy of your message.
When you study the most persuasive arguments, from Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s "I Have a Dream" speech, to award-winning TV commercials to the most effective politicians, you'll notice how the message is shaped to deliver these three promises.
As a next step, gather your team for a 30-minute discussion on how your product or service impacts the lives of your customers in these three ways. Once you're clear on it, these three promises can serve as a powerful foundation that shapes your overall approach to marketing and communication.
Three promises. One gigantic result.
Josh Linkner is a tech entrepreneur, New York Times bestselling author and keynote speaker. For information, visit joshlinkner.com.
Josh Linkner
Guest columnist
Josh Linkner

Worst-case scenario would call for drastic measures School closings? Canceled events? It's all possible. CORONAVIRUS IN CONNECTICUT

Autor: Putterman, Alex. 

Información de publicación: Hartford Courant ; Hartford, Conn. [Hartford, Conn]. 08 Mar 2020: A.6. [Duplicado]

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/worst-case-scenario-would-call-drastic-measures/docview/2373478950/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Worst-case+scenario+would+call+for+drastic+measures+School+closings%3F+Canceled+events%3F+It%27s+all+possible.+CORONAVIRUS+IN+CONNECTICUT&amp;author=Putterman%2C+Alex&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.6&amp;date=2020-03-08&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Hartford+Courant&amp;issn=1047-4153&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anortheastnews1_

Texto completo: As of now, doctors and public health officials have limited tools to combat COVID-19, the new strain of coronavirus that has quickly spread across the world.
There is no vaccine. There is no antiviral treatment. There is only preventing the spread through "social distancing," a term that encompasses everything from closing schools to shutting down parks and mass transit.
"When we are dealing with an epidemic, we reach in the tool box and pull out a vaccine," state epidemiologist Matthew Cartter said. "But [with coronavirus], we don't have that."
In a worst-case scenario, the implications for Connecticut could be far-reaching. Public schools could close, colleges could shut down, public places could be deserted, the upcoming presidential primary could be affected.
Cartter was clear Friday that Connecticut does not yet need drastic measures. No one knows exactly how quickly COVID-19 will move or how many people will become sick, though experts say most patients will self-recover, as they would after the flu. With only two confirmed cases linked to the state, Connecticut has not been hit as hard as others.
But given the possibility of large-scale outbreak and the lack of treatment options, wide closures could eventually become necessary, as officials seek to slow the spread enough to treat severe cases.
"Most of us do not remember the kind of control measures that are going to be needed to keep hospitals open, to keep taking care of the most seriously ill," Cartter said.
For the state to impose mass closures, Gov. Ned Lamont would have to declare a civil preparedness emergency, which would give him broad powers over public institutions. Brenda Bergeron, principal attorney for the Division of Emergency Management and Homeland Security, said Lamont's decision to take that step will depend on conversations with his unified command.
"The governor's office has the state agencies consider what they might need to waive or modify," Bergeron said, "and if there's a need for that, that's one of the reasons he might declare an emergency."
So far, governors in California, Washington, Florida and Maryland have declared states of emergency in response to COVID-19.
Across the world, regions with significant COVID-19 outbreaks have begun to take dramatic precautions. As of Tuesday, 22 countries on three continents had closed schools because of the virus, according to the United Nations, resulting in almost 300 million students left at home. In Italy, all professional soccer games will be played without any fans in attendance for the next month. Disneyland parks in Shanghai and Tokyo have been closed temporarily.
Public officials in the United States have begun to weigh similarly strong responses.
One public school district in Washington state has suspended classes for up to two weeks, and the University of Washington said Friday that it would cancel in-person classes and have students take courses and finals remotely while the Seattle area grapples with a growing outbreak. If the virus becomes more widespread, other colleges around the country could follow.
Over the last few days, a growing number of universities have mobilized emergency planning teams to envision what a shutdown would look like, especially if students bring the virus back with them from spring break, which started Friday on many campuses.
Already, some students have been warned that they should be prepared to learn online, as many students studying abroad in Europe and Asia have been forced to do.
On Friday, organizers canceled the South by Southwest festival in Austin, Texas, citing coronavirus. Closures and cancellations are likely to continue in coming weeks and months, as authorities consider even more dramatic responses, such as the cancellation of the Summer Olympics in Japan.
In Connecticut, the state Department of Education says it continues to coordinate with local school districts as they weigh potential responses. Until the state declares a civil preparedness emergency, decisions on school cancellations continue to fall to individual districts.
Writing in the New York Times, University of Michigan medical historian Howard Markel argued that school districts should err toward closing, citing his study on the 1918-19 flu pandemic.
"School closing turned out to be one of the most effective firewalls against the spread of the pandemic," he wrote. "Cities that acted fast, for lengthy periods of time, and included school closing and at least one other [non-pharmaceutical intervention] in their responses saw the lowest death rates."
Most states, including Connecticut, continue to hold widely attended events, such as the UConn men's basketball game in Storrs on Thursday night that drew more than 10,000 fans.
Asked whether those events pose danger, health officials said risk is limited as long as there is no community transmission - i.e. no residents are being infected here in Connecticut.
Travel restrictions could also expand along with the spread of the virus. Currently, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention have travel advisories of varying severity for five countries: China, Iran, Italy, South Korea and Japan, as well as Hong Kong.
Many colleges, including in Connecticut, have canceled school-related travel. UConn has urged students to cancel all non-essential international trips, including on spring break.
"The coronavirus situation continues to rapidly evolve; because of this, travel restrictions and guidance may also continue to change very quickly," UConn said in a statement.
