Chicago's top chefs

Autor: Vettel, Phil. 

Información de publicación: Chicago Tribune ; Chicago, Ill. [Chicago, Ill]. 05 Mar 2020: 6.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/chicagos-top-chefs/docview/2371059364/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Chicago%27s+top+chefs%3A+The+people+who+made+last+year+deliciously+memorable&amp;author=Vettel%2C+Phil&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=6&amp;date=2020-03-05&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Chicago+Tribune&amp;issn=1085-6706&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Achicagotribune_

Texto completo: The Chicago Tribune's Critic's Choice Food & Dining Awards honor the chefs who made 2019 so deliciously memorable. The lineup of excellence begins with our Chef of the Year, Erick Williams, and continues with impressive newcomers, ambitious veterans and at least two separate comeback stories.

Chef of the Year

Erick Williams, Virtue
It's no exaggeration to say that Erick Williams owned 2019. His Hyde Park restaurant, Virtue, won a three-star review from this critic, was named one of the country's best new restaurants by Eater in July, and one of the Best New Restaurants in America by Esquire magazine in November. In between, he was included in a New York Times story on "16 Black Chefs Changing Food in America," and received the Tribune's annual Game Changer award. Last week, he was named a semifinalist for the James Beard Foundation's Best Chef: Great Lakes award. All this while keeping his restaurant humming along, and maintaining grace and humility in the face of relentless praise.

Pastry Chef of the Year

Craig Harzewski, Brindille
Whether I've dined at Naha (for all of its 18 years) or Brindille (seven years and counting), one delightful constant has been the superior work by Craig Harzewski. Harzewski fashions complex, art-gallery-worthy desserts that never lose sight of the sheer joy of eating them, whether he's creating feather-soft clafoutis, chocolate cremeux with hazelnut spongecake, or a custardy blancmange with star-anise sorbet. All this while overseeing a terrific savory bread program. (I'm not the only voice praising Harzewski's work; earlier this year, the Jean Banchet Awards named Harzewski its Pastry Chef of the Year.) One of the many reasons to look forward to Carrie and Michael Nahabedian's Naha 2.0, or whatever it will be named, is that Harzewski will have yet another outlet for his artistry.

Rookie of the Year

Mariya Russell, Kumiko, Kikko
You can't help cheering for a chef who's put in charge of a kitchen for the very first time and proceeds to turn the opportunity into a Michelin star, and just last week, became a semifinalist for Best Chef: Great Lakes by the James Beard Foundation. Mariya Russell worked with Noah Sandoval at the late Senza and four-star Oriole before being named chef de cuisine at Kumiko and, four months later at Kikko, the intimate omakase bar built in Kumiko's basement. Diners have two ways of enjoying Russell's food -- either the a la carte bites menu upstairs (matched to Julia Momose's cocktail wizardry) or the 12-course menu downstairs, where you can watch the chef in action. There's no wrong choice.

Comeback of the Year

Carlos Gaytan, Tzuco
The talented Carlos Gaytan abruptly lost his 10-year-old Mexique restaurant in 2018, a reversal of fortune that sent the chef back to Mexico, where he created Ha, a highly regarded restaurant in Playa del Carmen. But Gaytan appeared periodically in town, at events such as Chicago Gourmet, in the interim, and by September he was back for good with Tzuco, a restaurant named after Gaytan's hometown of Huitzuco, and proceeded to take the Chicago dining scene by storm (Tzuco was just named a semifinalist for Best New Restaurant by the JBF). Here was Gaytan at his finest, cooking with a stronger sense of place than the fusion dishes that characterized Mexique, and demonstrating that, despite many setbacks, that talent will out.

Raising the Sushi Bar

B.K. Park, Mako
Since 1999, B.K. Park has been synonymous with sushi excellence in Chicago, thanks to his work at Mirai, Arami and Juno restaurants, but he exceeded even his own standards with the opening of Mako, an intimate, 22-seat temple where Park's near-silent ministrations can be viewed up close. At $175, Park's 16-course omakase menus are beyond the reach of many, but watching Park working in front of a black-and-gold background is like viewing a stage performance, and a brilliant one at that.

Keeping the Fire Burning

Carmen Lemons and Lynn Walker Harvey, Lem's Bar-B-Q
The history of Lem's Bar-B-Q and the legendary Lemons brothers goes back for decades (indeed, the business celebrated its 65th year last summer), but when the last brother, the great pitmaster James Lemons, died in 2015, his daughters were there to keep the torch aloft. Owner Carmen Lemons and sister, Lynn Walker Harvey, who began working at Lem's at 20 years old, not only have maintained the restaurant's sky-high standards, they've also worked to improve the place, completing a five-month renovation (remarkably, without shutting down) featuring new cabinetry, quartz tiles and doors. Eventually, the duo hopes to bring Lem's famed sauce, seasoning and hot links to retail markets. So many iconic Chicago operations vanish once the founder steps down or passes on. It's rare for someone to step up and keep the flame burning, and more rare to see it done this well.

The Engaging Sushi Chef

Otto Phan, Kyoten
Sushi dining can be as solemn as a religious rite, silent but for the occasional brief explanation of what the chef just handed you. Otto Phan shattered that mold when he moved here from Austin, Texas, in search of a bigger stage and -- he's not shy about saying so -- Michelin recognition. To dine at Phan's Kyoten is to enter a culinary conversation with a chef who cracks jokes, solicits on-the-fly feedback and happily explains the thinking behind his fish sourcing and rice selection. "I want every bite to be a home run," Phan says. Usually, it is. Phan didn't land a Michelin star his first year out, but just you wait.

Perfect Timing

Gene Kato, Momotaro
When opening chef Mark Hellyar resigned from Momotaro for family reasons, owners Kevin Boehm and Rob Katz wasted little time reaching out to Gene Kato, who had returned east after the closing of his Sumi Robata Bar. "The whole time I was in Charlotte (North Carolina), I was trying to get back," Kato said, and he quickly repacked his bags. In what has proved to be an ideal pairing, Momotaro was able to maintain its reputation as Chicago's finest Japanese restaurant, while Kato got the high-profile gig he has long deserved. Not to mention the backing for a new project, the Japanese-Italian Momotaro Italia, opening later this year (fingers crossed), and a Best Chef: Great Lakes nod (semifinalist) by the James Beard Foundation.<
CAPTION: Photo: Erick Williams of Virtue E. JASON WAMBSGANS/ CHICAGO TRIBUNE; Photo: Carlos Gaytan of Tzuco; Photo: Craig Harzewski of Brindille; Photo: Mariya Russell of Kumiko/Kikko E. JASON WAMBSGANS/CHICAGO TRIBUNE PHOTOS<
CREDIT: By Phil Vettel

Deadlocked in 3 elections, Israel seeks ways to avert 4th

Autor: Halbfinger, David M. 

Información de publicación: Chicago Tribune ; Chicago, Ill. [Chicago, Ill]. 05 Mar 2020: 14.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/deadlocked-3-elections-israel-seeks-ways-avert/docview/2371059294/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Deadlocked+in+3+elections%2C+Israel+seeks+ways+to+avert+4th&amp;author=Halbfinger%2C+David+M&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=14&amp;date=2020-03-05&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Chicago+Tribune&amp;issn=1085-6706&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Achicagotribune_

Texto completo: With Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's supporters for another term outnumbered by lawmakers who want him gone, Israel's political system -- having cranked through the motions of a third election in less than a year only to produce another stalemate -- began grappling Wednesday with what to do next.
A nearly complete vote count showed Netanyahu's coalition of right-wing and religious parties with 58 seats in the 120-seat Parliament, three short of a governing majority.
That leaves Israel more or less back at square one -- except that Netanyahu's trial on felony corruption charges starts March 17, his opponents appear exhausted by a campaign in which he outclassed them to achieve a solid plurality and no one in the country appears willing to contemplate a fourth ballot.
Netanyahu's Likud party sought to maximize its leverage as the largest faction to emerge from Monday's election, floating the possibility of its recruiting right-leaning lawmakers from the mostly left-leaning Labor-Gesher-Meretz alliance or from the centrist Blue and White party, headed by the former army chief Benny Gantz, who was Netanyahu's leading challenger.
But just one defector -- whose political career could be ended, analysts said, by such a betrayal of the voters who elected him or her -- would be a lot to ask. Three would seem a miracle, even for Netanyahu.
And the likeliest candidates to be wooed by Netanyahu all insisted they were holding fast to their promises to see him into retirement and could not be bought off, no matter the inducement.
The anti-Netanyahu forces, for their part, showed some new fight Wednesday.
Lawmakers from all three center-left parties said they would propose or support legislation to bar Israel's president from asking a lawmaker under indictment to form a government.
Ofer Shelah, of Blue and White, said the party would pursue measures in Parliament to block Netanyahu from serving as prime minister.
He noted that Israeli law now prohibits someone under indictment from serving as an ordinary government minister but does not specifically address the prime minister's position.
"We believe such a law is worthy," Shelah said.
Nitzan Horowitz, leader of the left-wing Meretz party, encouraged Blue and White to "go for it," saying, "It reflects the will of the public, and it's the moral thing to do."
Ahmed Tibi, of the predominantly Arab Joint List, which won a record 15 seats in Parliament on surprisingly strong turnout among Palestinian citizens of Israel, said it, too, would support such a law.
It was not clear whether Avigdor Liberman's ultranationalist Yisrael Beiteinu party, whose support would also be needed, would join in such an effort. His party emerged with seven seats, according to the unfinished tally.
Still, the idea of such a law drew howls from Netanyahu's supporters on the right, who said it would be retroactive and would not survive a court challenge.
Ayelet Shaked, a former justice minister from the right-wing Yamina party, accused the left, "which exalts democracy," of trying to use legislation to "cancel election results," and "with the aid of terror supporters" at that.
The term "terror supporters" referred to the Joint List, some members of which are accused by critics of having expressed sympathy for terrorists. Tibi is widely reviled among many Israeli Jews for, among other things, having been an adviser to Yasser Arafat, the longtime Palestinian leader.
Analysts said it was unlikely that the legislation barring an indicted lawmaker from serving as prime minister would be approved, in part because of the political storm it could kick up. But several suggested that the anti-Netanyahu parties were making a point as the jockeying over coalition talks begins.
CAPTION: Photo: Israeli election vote totals show Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is three seats short of a governing majority. DAN BALILTY/THE NEW YORK TIMES
CREDIT: By David M. Halbfinger, The New York Times

Top reasons to read 'The Top 10 as We Hit Bottom'

Autor: Alkon, Jim. 

Información de publicación: Chicago Tribune ; Chicago, Ill. [Chicago, Ill]. 05 Mar 2020: 3.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/top-reasons-read-10-as-we-hit-bottom/docview/2371059289/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Top+reasons+to+read+%27The+Top+10+as+We+Hit+Bottom%27&amp;author=Alkon%2C+Jim&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=3&amp;date=2020-03-05&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Chicago+Tribune&amp;issn=1085-6706&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Achicagotribune_

Texto completo: 'The Top 10 as We Hit Bottom'
By Jim Parry, illustrated by Ron Barrett, Skyhorse Publishing, 272 pages, $17.99
Since Ron Barrett illustrated the classic children's picture book "Cloudy With a Chance of Meatballs" in 1978, the forecast for our world has become considerably more dire.
Fast-forward 42 years to "The Top 10 as We Hit Bottom," a darkly satirical but real collection of top 10 lists that highlight the predicament global warming and other impending catastrophes have put us into. The book has been researched and written by Jim Parry and illustrated by Barrett.
Although some might call this book a collection of "fake news," the lists are compiled and culled from respected authorities like NASA, the United Nations and the Union of Concerned Scientists. The creators think the heartwarming illustrations, to temper the harsh messages of the text, will have readers laughing their way all the way down in the race to the bottom.
The book's cover, reminiscent of the box for Screaming Yellow Zonkers (are you with me?), says the lists have been compiled by The Center for Impending Doom, for which Parry, voted Class Cynic of his high school graduating class, claims to be the founder.
The Top 10 may not solve any of these earthly issues, but can go a long way to increase awareness among the population. Among the topics of note: global warming, nuclear war, cyberwar, biowar, pandemics, earthquakes, tsunamis, supervolcanoes, blizzards, hurricanes and tornadoes.
Pumped yet? OK: avalanches, landslides, wildfires, floods, droughts, famines, asteroids, alien attacks, solar storms, doomsdays past and future. There, feel better?
So here's 10 of the many Top 10 lists to whet your appetite for Earth's impending doom:
"Top 10 species we'll lose to climate change"
"Top 10 avalanches mostly caused by global warming"
"Top 10 climate change doubters"
"Top 10 times we almost had a nuclear war"
"Top 10 things that will happen when the Yellowstone Supervolcano erupts"
"Top 10 ways to try to stop an asteroid"
"Top 10 signs that the earth is about to be swallowed by a black hole"
"Top 10 ways a particle accelerator mishap could destroy the world"
"Top 10 end-of-world cults you can join now"
"Top 10 ways aliens could kill us all"
So why did Barrett, a legendary children's book illustrator, take on this project? "It's not a very long journey," he said. "The New York Times recently recommended 'Cloudy With a Chance of Meatballs' as one of the best books to teach children about climate change. It is, after all, a book about the weather gone awry. Unfortunately we have no toast boats to escape from becoming toast ourselves."
"I feel very strongly that the earth will become uninhabitable unless we do something to eliminate all carbon emissions by tomorrow morning. Yet Parry's meticulously researched book is about more than warming -- it's all the ways forces in and out of our control threaten our existence."
The lists are more than just lists. Listen to Parry's introduction of the top species we'll lose to climate change: "The polar bear is the poster-creature of climate change victims, but these ten (on the list) are actually closer to extinction. One of them -- a mosaic-tailed rat -- is already gone. Oh, we don't care about losing a rat? Hey, just as rats leaving a sinking ship is a warning, maybe we should be warned."
The titles of some of the lists are enough to arouse curiosity, or at least make you read them a second time: "The Top 10 Steps by Which the Biggest Opportunity to Combat Global Warming Was Lost, 1979-1989." Let me see, where was I in 1979?
Or: "The Top 10 Ways the Universe Could -- Tomorrow or 2,000 Billion Years From Now -- End."
Among the Top 10 Quotes About the End of the World, here's one from Mark Twain: "When the end of the world comes, I want to be in Kentucky, because everything there happens 20 years after it happens anywhere else."
Wasn't life so much simpler when your only worry was whether it would be raining meatballs later in the afternoon?
CAPTION: Photo: 'The Top 10 as We Hit Bottom' ; By Jim Parry, illustrated by Ron Barrett, Skyhorse Publishing, 272 pages, $17.99
CREDIT: By Jim Alkon, Tribune News Service

Biden's super comeback adds to Trump's bad week

Autor: Haberman, Maggie; Karni, Annie. 

Información de publicación: Chicago Tribune ; Chicago, Ill. [Chicago, Ill]. 05 Mar 2020: 13.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/bidens-super-comeback-adds-trumps-bad-week/docview/2371059276/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Biden%27s+super+comeback+adds+to+Trump%27s+bad+week&amp;author=Haberman%2C+Maggie%3BKarni%2C+Annie&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=13&amp;date=2020-03-05&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Chicago+Tribune&amp;issn=1085-6706&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Achicagotribune_

Texto completo: With eight months until Election Day, President Donald Trump is having a bad week.
Despite Trump's concerted efforts to paint Joe Biden as corrupt -- an attempt that led directly to his own impeachment -- the former vice president pulled off one of the most remarkable political comebacks in recent history Tuesday, reemerging as the front-runner for the Democratic presidential nomination and Trump's opponent in November.
The stock markets tumbled again Tuesday amid fears about the ongoing spread of the coronavirus around the world, and by midmorning Wednesday, yet another case of the virus was confirmed in New York.
But futures markets bounced up Wednesday with the news of Biden's victories, after he won states across the South and Midwest by large margins and dealt a serious blow to the prospects of Sen. Bernie Sanders.
For Trump, whose belief in his own ability to shape external events is a source of comfort, it means now confronting a moment when almost nothing is in his control.
He has dealt with the coronavirus, the first external crisis of his administration, by repeating a string of falsehoods rather than delivering reassurance. And his insistence that his administration deserves an "A+++" for its response has done little to calm the rattled markets or an anxious electorate.
Biden even won the primary in Texas, a state that several Trump advisers saw as a bellwether given the makeup of its electorate.
Trump's aides said they are now preparing for a scorched-earth campaign against Biden in the coming months, even as voters Tuesday appeared to favor a candidate who projected calm stability over upheaval and uncertainty.
A sign of Trump's frustration was evident in one of his morning tweets Wednesday -- a screed against Jeff Sessions, the former attorney general who was forced into a runoff Tuesday night for his old Senate seat in Alabama, and whom Trump still blames for the two-year probe into possible conspiracy between the president's 2016 campaign and Russian officials.
"This is what happens to someone who loyally gets appointed Attorney General of the United States & then doesn't have the wisdom or courage to stare down & end the phony Russia Witch Hunt. Recuses himself on FIRST DAY in office, and the Mueller Scam begins!" Trump posted on Twitter, after Sessions fell short of securing a majority in the Republican primary in the Senate race.
For months, Trump has told aides he believes he can shape the Democratic race to his own advantage by focusing on specific candidates. And he has been more overt than any incumbent in trying to influence the nominating contest of another party, training his Twitter feed on his potential rivals and trying to deepen authentic divisions in the Democratic Party by stoking fears that the establishment was trying to rob Sanders of the nomination.
He floated the idea in January that the Senate impeachment trial was designed to keep Sanders grounded in Washington instead of campaigning in Iowa ahead of the caucuses there.
That month, Trump aides also began to see Sanders as their ideal Democratic opponent in November and sought to elevate his profile.
Another target was Michael Bloomberg, a longtime rival from New York who had no compunction contrasting his wealth with Trump's.
Bloomberg's withdrawal from the race Wednesday may provide Trump with a small measure of comfort. But it also presents a challenge for his campaign, as Bloomberg has promised to spend $1 billion to help the Democratic nominee and threw his support to Biden.
But Bloomberg was not the main concern of Trump and his advisers. For months, they fanned the flames about Biden's younger son, Hunter, and his work for Burisma, an energy company in Ukraine. That effort was central to the impeachment inquiry into whether Trump tried to pressure Ukrainians to investigate the Bidens in exchange for releasing military aid.
The damage to Trump was obvious, but the former vice president's candidacy also suffered in the process.
But the revival of Biden -- who was buoyed by black voters, a core Democratic Party constituency, in several states -- illustrates the limits of Trump's influence.
"I think Democratic primary voters are numbing to Trump's buffoonery -- black voters in particular," said Addisu Demissie, who managed Sen. Cory Booker's presidential campaign. "They are the ones who have breathed life back into Biden's campaign and, if anything, they may relish seeing Biden take him down."
CAPTION: Photo: President Trump's aides are preparing for a scorched-earth campaign against Joe Biden. DOUG MILLS/THE NEW YORK TIMES
CREDIT: By Maggie Haberman and Annie Karni, The New York Times

____________________________________________________________

Crossroads Church uses donations to wipe out $46.5M in medical debt

Autor: Mitchell, Madeline. 

Información de publicación: Cincinnati Enquirer ; Cincinnati, Ohio [Cincinnati, Ohio]. 05 Mar 2020: A.1. [Duplicado]

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/crossroads-church-uses-donations-wipe-out-46-5m/docview/2371056615/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Crossroads+Church+uses+donations+to+wipe+out+%2446.5M+in+medical+debt&amp;author=Mitchell%2C+Madeline&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.1&amp;date=2020-03-05&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Cincinnati+Enquirer&amp;issn=2575-5706&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Amidwestnews1_

Texto completo: Crossroads Church senior pastor Brian Tome mentioned the campaign nearly in passing.
He spent about three minutes describing the burden of medical debt during his Nov. 23 sermon, entitled "The Marks of Multiplication." Tome said members of the congregation could text "MULTIPLY" to 313131 to help "free others from medical debt," but insisted the campaign was not a challenge.
Just an awareness.
It was also a great metaphor for his lesson on multiplicity.
"When we are in debt, a sin debt to God, we can't get our way out of the sin debt to God," he said during the sermon. "Jesus comes and gives himself so we can pay off our sin debt, so we never have to worry about God hurting us for our sin."
Crossroads could give to free others' debt, too, he said. And for every dollar they raised, Crossroad's partner RIP Medical Debt would leverage that dollar to abolish $100 in medical debt, therefore multiplying the church's impact.
Within a week and a half, members of the Crossroads community donated enough to abolish over $46.5 million in medical debt nationwide.
Over $42 million of those funds came back to Ohio families.
"Most of it probably that weekend," said Crossroads director of marketing Brennan Hill. "Cuz I think most people, if I had to guess, were doing it in real time. You know, if they were literally getting their phones out and texting in."
Church officials announced the impact of their campaign on Feb. 23.
Most of the funds came back to Ohio families since the church is based out of the Cincinnati region. But the sermons are streamed online, which means anyone in the nation can tune in and participate.
RIP Medical Debt is able to track the donations back to their original ZIP codes to give back. So, if you donated from Indiana, your donation was multiplied and given back to your community in Indiana.
In Ohio, church officials say, they have abolished $42.8 million in debts across 41,233 households in 103 ZIP codes.
They also abolished $1.9 million in debt across 2,974 Kentucky households, $1.5 million across 503 Tennessee households and $200,000 across 136 Indiana households.
What is RIP Medical Debt? An article posted by USA Today last year explains that RIP Medical Debt is a nonprofit organization based out of Rye, New York, that arranges debt payoffs.
The article said medical debt contributes to two-thirds of bankruptcies, according to the American Journal of Public Health. And a 2018 Kaiser Family Foundation/New York Times poll showed that of the 26 percent of people who reported problems paying medical bills, 59 percent reported a major life impact, such as taking an extra job, cutting other household spending or using up savings.
"How sad that probably the only debt that you don't choose to get – cuz you don't choose to get sick – and it's the one that's affecting most people," said Victor Martinez, spiritual growth site leader for the Oakley location.
When a person can't pay a bill, that debt is often packaged with other people's debt and sold to bill collectors for some fraction of the total amount of the bill. RIP Medical Debt buys debt portfolios on this secondary market for pennies on the dollar with money from its donors.
But instead of collecting the debt, RIP forgives it.
To be eligible for repayment from RIP, the debtor must be earning less than twice the federal poverty level (about $25,000 a year for an individual and $52,000 for a family of four), have debts that are 5% or more of their annual income and have more debt than assets.
Because hospitals and doctors are eager to get those hard-to-collect debts off their books, they sell them cheap.
Working this way puts a high-dollar project within reach of even small churches. Revolution Annapolis, a nondenominational Maryland church with Sunday attendance of around 200 and without a permanent building, wiped out $1.9 million in debt for 900 families in March. Total amount raised: $15,000.
A debt that never goes away... even if you don't know about it According to the Federal Trade Commission, debt collectors have a certain number of years they can sue you and win to collect a debt. This rule is called the statute of limitations, and is six years in Ohio.
This means that for any type of debt, a creditor cannot sue a debtor for debt collection purposes after six years, according to America's Debt Help Organization. That timeframe begins when someone fails to make a payment on a debt. The clock will start again if you make a payment or provide written acknowledgment of your debt after the first six years are up.
Martinez says that because of this law, many people who got a letter explaining that their debt had been abolished thanks to Crossroads didn't even know they had medical debt. If it was after those six years, hospitals and debt collectors had stopped calling.
"If those six years pass, then nobody can give you a call asking for that money," Martinez said. "But you still owe that money, technically. And the only way that you can really get rid of it is if you file bankruptcy, or if you pay for it."
Medical debt never goes away. It will stay on your record if you don't pay it. The law just states that if you don't pay it within that six year window, people will stop asking you to pay – not that you are off the hook.
Martinez said that now that he understands how the law works, he's afraid to call and ask if he owes anything. Because, what if he owes a lot of money? He'll be accountable to pay it, he said.
"That is very scary," he said. "Because what if I have medical debt that I don't know about?"
'A great analogy to what Jesus did for us.' Crossroads officials did not want this story to be about them.
"We kept it off social media," Hill said. "We really want it to be about people in our community, like I said, who are currently giving."
Crossroads members don't know who specifically they have impacted. They could not choose whose debt to pay off. In a letter to each debtor, Crossroads explained the campaign and said that they hope to provide more resources for those in need, whether that is through prayer or connecting them with healthcare professionals in their community.
"We don't want this to be the last interaction that we have with them, but there are no strings attached," Hill said."We just hope that they understand who Crossroads is, what our heart is for the community, maybe set foot in one of our sites."
This whole experience has been a great analogy to what Jesus did for us, Martinez said.
"Jesus, before we knew who he was, he died for us, to forgive our debt," Martinez said. "And here, we don't know who these people are, and we are putting this money for their debt to be forgiven."
According to RIP Medical Debt, Crossroads' campaign is its largest amount of medical debt that's ever been retired. The nonprofit's site claims that its partnerships have erased almost $1.4 billion in medical debt to date.
Crossroads Church senior pastor Brian Tome mentioned the campaign nearly in passing during his Nov. 23 sermon, yet within a week and a half, members of the Crossroads community donated enough to abolish over $46.5 million in medical debt nationwide.
CREDIT: Madeline Mitchell

Buttigieg has a bright future in politics and government

Información de publicación: Indianapolis Star ; Indianapolis, Ind. [Indianapolis, Ind]. 05 Mar 2020: A.1.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/buttigieg-has-bright-future-politics-government/docview/2371055495/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=unknown&amp;atitle=Buttigieg+has+a+bright+future+in+politics+and+government&amp;author=&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.1&amp;date=2020-03-05&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Indianapolis+Star&amp;issn=1930-2533&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Amidwestnews1_

Texto completo: I was sorry to see the Hoosier candidate, Pete Buttigieg, did not get further in his quest for the presidency. But he is a young man with a bright future in politics and government.
Hopefully a new president will appoint him to a position where Buttigieg can put to use his talent in speaking several languages, along with his military experience and the foreign policy knowledge he displayed in several debates – such as secretary of state or secretary of defense or a high position in either important department. Once he pads his resume he can run again for a higher office like the U.S. Senate, or even once again for the presidency armed with greater name recognition and even more experience. His issues were the issues of the future: abolishing the Electoral College, automatic voter registration and abolishing Senate filibuster.
Mike Boland
Fishers
Keep Indy's mature trees standing in neighborhoods We have lived in our neighborhood since we moved here 30 years ago. It is a nice family-friendly neighborhood. During the summer you see kids playing outside, families walking their dogs, and neighbors interacting with each other. It is a beautiful neighborhood with beautiful mature trees that provide shade for the neighborhood.
Recently, the City-County Council decided that we needed a walking path along the main street in our neighborhood. So last month they had all the big, beautiful trees along our main street chopped down, and I am sure that it was not cheap to do that. My understanding is that the next step is to tear up the sidewalk and add a blacktopped walking path, which I am sure is not going to be cheap either.
In speaking with my neighbors, a number of them had stated that they did not want this done, but would have liked to had not only the sidewalk repaired, but also have the pavement on the main street redone. This street has patches on top of patches and is very bumpy to drive over. My question to the City-County Council is, why are you spending money on taking down big, beautiful mature trees and something that really didn't need to be replace, when there are major items items that needed attention first?
Annie Darragh
Indianapolis
Religious people can pray for others – and take action It saddens me that people mock the term "thoughts and prayers." I want to bring awareness to people that just because someone is praying for something, does not mean that they aren't taking action. It doesn't mean they are also not voting, or writing to their members of Congress, or fundraising or whatever needs to be done to create change.
Furthermore, to some, prayer is the most powerful act they can do. To those who believe, prayer is speaking to God, the one who can do and undo all things. Why would you mock someone who has the intention to speak to God on the behalf of someone else to help them? There are countries in which both work and school are not in session because the people need to go to prayer. That is the extent of how important it is to some. It saddens me that we take away the dignity of religious people by assuming they don't care instead of being grateful for them praying on behalf of us or others.
Emilia Bell
Indianapolis
Indiana should remain on one time zone We all have flipped our calendars and have noticed that on Sunday, Americans are forced to abide by taking an hour away from their sleep to support daylight saving time. Isn't it time to end this nonsense? There may have been a time when daylight saving time was useful, but we don't need it now. I ask, why do we have to do this?
Messing with our body time clock is dangerous healthwise and can cause many vehicular accidents the next morning after we change our clock. I remember the bus driver and one child who died the day after the hour change in Indianapolis a few years ago.
Americans need to demand this nonsense of jumping forward each spring be stopped. Indiana needs to stay on one time zone and remain there as well as the entire nation.
Mari Briggs
Sheridan
Treat substance abuse as a health issue, not a criminal one I once believed in a post-racial society. I was taught the realities of racism were in days past, and that those who were had been shunned, eradicated even. According to Bryan Stevenson of the New York Times, more black and brown people are incarcerated than there ever were slaves at the peak of slavery. The United States of America accounts for 5% of the world's population, yet 25% of the world's prison population. Policies that support this incarceration are locking up nonviolent individuals over narcotics possession, and treating them like they hurt someone, when they were just trying to cope with their situation. Substance use disorder is a disease, yet is treated criminally, resulting in citizens feeling isolated and having high rearrest levels. Incentive in law enforcement to arrest more people for financing is problematic; it's perpetuating a cycle of class suppression via felony labeling.
State legalization of cannabis coupled with expunging of felony records associated to the substance, as well as reforming incentives for arrests in law enforcement, and funding more appropriate substance use disorder treatment centers is needed. This could help pave the way for a future where substance abuse is treated as a health issue as opposed to a criminal one. In a state where our religious and legislative freedom has become one in the same, I ask us to take purely a humanistic approach.
Alex Peacock Jr.
Indianapolis
Lack of oversight of Indiana's charter schools is 'appalling' Wake up, voters. Pay attention to what Republican state legislators are doing to fund charter schools and vouchers. Do you really want your tax dollars going to charter schools? To private schools? To schools with a religious agenda? Considering Rep. Jeff Thompson was a public school teacher, I am shocked to see his support of charter schools in his sponsoring of House Bill 1065 where public school boards may share tax referendum funds with charter schools. This is just a short step to shall and should not be permitted.
This bill is just one of several where the state legislators have funneled money to non-public schools. The lack of oversight of charter schools is appalling, yet legislators continue to skim public funds for these pseudo-public schools. They are not really public schools. In rural areas, the public schools are often the center of community activities, yet legislators from rural areas go along with subsidies for charter and private schools. Oppose not just this proposal to permit the use of public money but to all of the legislative gyrations taking your tax dollars away from public schools. Wake up.
Linda Robb
Indianapolis
Voters must take a close look at Sanders Bernie Sanders used to rail against millionaires and billionaires. Has anyone noticed that since his book deal made him a millionaire, he now rails against only billionaires.
Which leads me to ask some questions: If Sanders has his way, will we all be millionaires, or will he give away his books for free to reduce his net worth to non-millionaire level? Will we all have three homes, or will he give his extra two to a couple of deserving homeless families? Will we all fly by private jet, or will he join the working class in coach?
What if his heart doctor tells him "I can't maintain my practice at Medicare reimbursement levels" – will he seek a less skilled physician to care for his heart, or will he pay extra for treatment, then join his doctor in jail for providing the service outside the government system?
Sanders and his fans ought to take another good look at the law of unintended consequences.
Eddie Bratton
Danville

Colleges Against Cancer Hope Dinner: 5 p.m. March 7, F.K. Bemis International Center, St. Norbert College, De Pere. $40 general public, $20 students; snc.edu/go/hopedinner. Includes a plated dinner, dessert and access to a silent auction. Multiple speakers throughout the evening will discuss how cancer has affected their lives. More info: email cac@snc.edu.
Meat Raffle for Leukemia/Lymphoma Society, 1-4 p.m. March 7, T&C Bar and Grill, 1358 Mid Valley Drive, Lawrence. Buy a number for a few bucks, watch the wheel spin and win packaged meat products as well as other items that will be in the raffle. All proceeds go to Leukemia/Lymphoma Society.
Throwback Prom for American Red Cross 2020: 6 p.m.-midnight March 7, Green Bay Distillery, 835 Mike McCarthy Way, Ashwaubenon. , Green Bay. Theme is "Disco for Disasters," a tribute to the iconic Studio 54 dance club and the proms of the 1970's. Music by Elite Music Service and Madison-based disco/funk cover band VO5, corny prom photos, a prom court competition featuring community members vying for your donations to win the title of prom king and queen, hors d'oeuvres, cash bar, assorted raffles and silent auction items. Advance tickets $30 for single, $40 for couple at all DuBois Formalwear stores in Green Bay area. Tickets at the door $45 single, $55 couple.
March 7-8, 12-15
2020 Spring Showcase of Homes: 10 a.m.-4 p.m. March 7-8, 14-15; 4-7 p.m. March 12-13. Presale tickets are $12 through March 6; $15 starting March 7. Check out 37 newly constructed and two remodeled homes by Brown County Home Builders Association members. Start at any home and visit each one at your own leisure. The remodeled projects will be showcased March 14 and 15. Go to BCHBA.org to purchase your tickets online, or to find a list of ticket sale locations.
March 12
Great Decisions Lecture Series: "Artificial Intelligence and Data": 6:30-7:30 p.m. March 12, Fort Howard Theater of F.K. Beamis International Center, St. Norbert College, De Pere. Presenter is Frederic Lemieux, faculty director and professor of practice for applied intelligence at Georgetown University. Free.
March 14
10th Annual Beer & Biscuits: 6:30-9:30 p.m. March 14, Stadium View Bar and Grille, 1963 Holmgren Way, Ashwaubenon. A night of wine, beer, cheese and dessert from more than 20 local vendors. Fundraiser for Happily Ever After Animal Sanctuary. General admission tickets $30 at heanokill.org, in person at HEA's Green Bay Adoption Center, Stadium View or Festival Foods De Pere, Howard and Green Bay locations.

6:30 Concert Series: "Future/Primitive: Percussion & Technology": 6:30 p.m. March 10, Cofrin Family Hall at the Weidner Center, UW-Green Bay. UWGB Music assistant professor Bill Sallak will explore the intersection of percussion historical roots with today's modern technology. Among the pieces to be performed is Pulitzer-Prize-winner John Luther Adams' "wail" from "Mathematics of Resonant Bodies," Eric Richards' "Finalbells," Alvin Lucier's "Nothing is Real." Free.

You can dance, you can jive, having the time of your life when ABBA-Mania takes over the Ashwaubenon Performing Arts Center on Saturday night. The all-Canadian tribute act has been playing the music of ABBA to sold-out crowds across North America for nearly 20 years and has earned praise from The New York Times and Chicago Tribune. You'll get the costumes and all the hits, including "Dancing Queen," "Mamma Mia," "Waterloo," "S.O.S." and "Gimme, Gimme, Gimme." Tickets start at $39 at ashwaubenonpac.org and (920) 494-3401.
The classic cars of The Automobile Gallery & Event Center in downtown Green Bay, including this 1967 Corvette once owned by Bart Starr, provide the backdrop for the Shamrock Craft Beer Invitational from 3 to 6 p.m. Saturday. Guests can sample more than 50 beers, snack on artisan cheeses and pizza and enjoy Irish music by Gerry Sloan. Tickets are $40 at TheAutomobileGallery.org or 920-437-9024.

Try these new restaurants at the Jersey Shore

Autor: Griesemer, Sarah. 

Información de publicación: Home News Tribune ; East Brunswick, N.J. [East Brunswick, N.J]. 05 Mar 2020: B.2.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/try-these-new-restaurants-at-jersey-shore/docview/2371038056/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Try+these+new+restaurants+at+the+Jersey+Shore&amp;author=Griesemer%2C+Sarah&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=B.2&amp;date=2020-03-05&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Home+News+Tribune&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anortheastnews1_

Texto completo: Looking for a new pizza place, coffee shop or cozy cocktail lounge?
How about a sub shop, smoothie bowl stop or healthy food spot?
All of these and more – including the return of a long-shuttered Asbury Park restaurant – have opened recently or are soon will at the Shore; take a look.
Round Pie Pizza Company, Matawan Brothers Kash and Bek Miftari are New York pizza royalty: Their father and uncles own Pronto Pizza, with five locations on Staten Island.
Pronto is known for its pan pizza, but when the younger Miftaris branched out on their own two years ago and opened Round Pie on the island, they went thin crust. They added a location in Old Bridge last summer, and a Matawan restaurant is opening soon. The brothers are hoping for mid-March.
Round Pie's signature pizza has mozzarella, plum tomato sauce, Parmigiana, extra-virgin olive oil and fresh basil. Omit all but the mozzarella and tomato sauce for their classic cheese pie, and fresh mozzarella makes a Margherita. Add garlic puree to the signature for a grandma-style pie.
And while pizza is the go-to here, we have our eye on the beef and pea-stuffed rice balls, served Parmigiana style.
Go: 1124 Route 34; 732-582-0000, roundpie.com. Also at 2323 Route 516 in Old Bridge, 732-475-0000, and 1957 Victory Blvd. in Staten Island; 718-524-0000.
Shore Fresh Meal Prep + Kitchen, Toms River Three years ago, Dan Carroll had open-heart surgery. A quintuple bypass.
He was 30 years old.
The experience kick-started a journey to a healthier lifestyle.
Carroll has a culinary background, and opened a business that offers healthy food for people on the go.
"We're geared toward everyone, not just toward body-builders," Carroll said a few days prior to the March 1 opening of Shore Fresh Meal Prep + Kitchen. (The store, ironically, is opening in the Hooper Avenue space previously occupied by Dozenz Donuts.) "We're custom meal prep. It's all about being able to grab it and go."
Carroll, who is 34 years old and lives in the Bayville section of Berkeley Township, attended culinary school in Maine and worked the kitchens of Spring Lake Bath & Tennis Club and Manasquan River Golf Club. He owns Shore Fresh with Frank Guzman, 45, of the Forked River section of Lacey.
Each meal, priced between $8 and $12, comes with a protein, starch and vegetable. Carroll said he will offer around 15 meal options a day, including sweet Asian meatballs or Buffalo chicken meatballs with rice and asparagus, Teriyaki Hangar Steak with sweet potatoes and green beans, and Balsamic-Glazed Bell & Evans chicken with red bliss potatoes and broccoli. Diners can heat their food and eat at the restaurant, or take it to go.
Go: 1846 Hooper Ave.; 732-272-2029, shorefreshmealprep.org.
Una Pizza Napoletana, Atlantic Highlands From New Jersey to New York City and back again, Anthony Mangieri's highly anticipated new restaurant opened Feb. 28.
Why all the fuss? In a review last year, The New York Times restaurant critic Pete Wells said that at Una Pizza Napoletana in lower Manhattan, "Mr. Mangieri makes what is unmistakably the finest sit-down pizza in the five boroughs."
But before becoming one of the city's premier pizzaioli, he was perfecting his pillowy, slightly charred pizzas at Una Pizza Napoletana in Point Pleasant Beach in the late 1990s. He is known for selling only whole pies — no slices, and just recently began allowing diners to customize their toppings.
"My plan was always to end up back in New Jersey and do what I love in the place that I love," Mangieri told The Asbury Park Press last year.
The 30-seat restaurant, which is co-owned by Garry Borealo, 58, of Roselle Park, will be open Fridays through Sundays at first, as Mangieri, who lives in New York City, divides his time between his two restaurants. The doors open at 5 p.m. and close when they run out of dough.
Go: 91A First Ave.; unapizza.com. Also at 175 Orchard St. in New York City; 646-692-3475.
Other restaurant news: Antoinetta's Waterfront Restaurant, West Creek: Closed. The restaurant owners, who had leased the waterfront space on Cedar Run Dock Road, report the property owners have listed the building for sale.
Beans N' Cream, Howell: The coffee shop, which also serves crepes, Belgian waffles and baked goods, opened Feb 23. 4224 Route 9.
Brooklyn Bistro, Toms River: The Italian restaurant closed its downtown Toms River location in early January and reopened in February in the Silverton section of the township. Brooklyn Bistro opened in the space previously occupied by Jules Italian Restaurant. 1861 Hooper Ave.; 732-244-2122; brooklynbistronj.com.
Franny's Pizzeria & Restaurant, Atlantic Highlands: After purchasing Francesco's Italian Restaurant in May 2019, Mya Anitai and Matt Marcus renovated the space and reopened as Franny's Pizzeria in January. Anitai also owns the restaurant Dinamo in Richmond, Virginia, and Marcus is the owner of three bars in New York. 279 Bay Ave.; 732-872-0080, frannyshighlands.com.
Lentil Tree, Asbury Park: The cafe, which closed more than a year ago, announced Feb. 26 via social media that it would reopen in mid-March: "Lentil Tree is coming back to life. Reintroducing a cultural blend of mouthwatering Turkish, Egyptian and Mediterranean cuisine. With both indoor and outdoor dining areas you can come, relax and allow our chefs to do the cooking for you." 808 5th Ave.; lentiltree.com.
Little Mia's Pizza, Toms River: The pizzeria and Italian restaurant, which is under construction, joins Bada Bean Cawfee and Jersey Shore Brewing Co. in The Shoppes at Hooper Avenue.
Long Branch Distillery, Long Branch: The 5,000-square-foot distillery, tasting room and lounge had a soft opening Feb. 20 and is open Thursdays through Sundays. Vodka and gin are currently being produced, along with craft cocktails. 199 Westwood Ave. 732-759-8321, lbdistillery.com.
Mystic Meat & Seafood Market, Stafford: Phil Tretola opened his Tuckerton deli, butcher shop and meat market in 2018, then added a Ship Bottom location this February. Next up, a franchise location in Manahawkin: Mystic Subs, owned by franchisee Jay Zimmerman of Tuckerton, will be located in the Manahawkin Mart Shoppes space previously occupied by Shore Fire Grille. As of press time, the anticipated opening date was April 1. 657 E Bay Ave.; mysticmeatandseafood.com.
Playa Bowls, Stafford: The acai berry bowl restaurant chain, which has more than 80 locations across the country, will open March 15 in the Main Street space previously occupied by cupcake shop Smallcakes. 399 N. Main St.; playabowls.com.
Umberto's Pizzeria, Fair Haven: The Italian restaurant and pizzeria on River Road announced March 2 that it would close March 28 after more than 30 years in business.
Ye Olde Pie Shoppe, Little Silver: The longtime bakery closed at the end of January.
"With bittersweet emotions, we announce our retirement after more than 35 years of rolling in the dough at Ye Olde Pie Shoppe," owners Eileen and Tom Caruso announced via social media. "Our journey began by taking a 'whisk' back in 1984 and purchasing a pie shop inside Andy's Market in Middletown from two local ladies. After a couple of years, we ran out of room and moved to our sugar-coated kitchen in Little Silver Shops.
"We are ready to take the apron off, put away the rolling pin and shut down the ovens. We're looking forward to sharing some new adventures and life experiences."
A lifelong Jersey girl, Sarah Griesemer joined the USA TODAY NETWORK New Jersey more than 15 years ago.
Send restaurant tips to sgriesemer@ gannettnj.com and follow
@jersey.shore.eats.
A pizza from Franny's Pizzeria & Restaurant, previously Francesco's Italian Restaurant, in Highlands.
COURTESY OF MYA ANITAI
Anthony Mangieri, a Jersey Shore native who is considered one of the top pizza makers in the United States, returns to New Jersey with Una Pizza Napoletana in downtown Atlantic Highlands.
Doug Hood/Staff photographer

Biden's super comeback adds to Trump's bad week analysis

Autor: Haberman, Maggie; Karni, Annie. 

Información de publicación: Orlando Sentinel ; Orlando, Fla. [Orlando, Fla]. 05 Mar 2020: A.3.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/bidens-super-comeback-adds-trumps-bad-week/docview/2370990238/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Biden%27s+super+comeback+adds+to+Trump%27s+bad+week+analysis&amp;author=Haberman%2C+Maggie%3BKarni%2C+Annie&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.3&amp;date=2020-03-05&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Orlando+Sentinel&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Asoutheastnews_

Texto completo: NEW YORK - With eight months until Election Day, President Donald Trump is having a bad week.
Despite Trump's concerted efforts to paint Joe Biden as corrupt - an attempt that led directly to his own impeachment - the former vice president pulled off one of the most remarkable political comebacks in recent history Tuesday, reemerging as the front-runner for the Democratic presidential nomination and Trump's opponent in November.
The stock markets tumbled again Tuesday amid fears about the ongoing spread of the coronavirus around the world, and by midmorning Wednesday, yet another case of the virus was confirmed in New York.
But futures markets bounced up Wednesday with the news of Biden's victories, after he won states across the South and Midwest by large margins and dealt a serious blow to the prospects of Sen. Bernie Sanders.
For Trump, whose belief in his own ability to shape external events is a source of comfort, it means now confronting a moment when almost nothing is in his control.
He has dealt with the coronavirus, the first external crisis of his administration, by repeating a string of falsehoods rather than delivering reassurance. And his insistence that his administration deserves an "A+++" for its response has done little to calm the rattled markets or an anxious electorate.
Biden even won the primary in Texas, a state that several Trump advisers saw as a bellwether given the makeup of its electorate.
Trump's aides said they are now preparing for a scorched-earth campaign against Biden in the coming months, even as voters Tuesday appeared to favor a candidate who projected calm stability over upheaval and uncertainty.
A sign of Trump's frustration was evident in one of his morning tweets Wednesday - a screed against Jeff Sessions, the former attorney general who was forced into a runoff Tuesday night for his old Senate seat in Alabama, and whom Trump still blames for the two-year probe into possible conspiracy between the president's 2016 campaign and Russian officials.
"This is what happens to someone who loyally gets appointed Attorney General of the United States & then doesn't have the wisdom or courage to stare down & end the phony Russia Witch Hunt. Recuses himself on FIRST DAY in office, and the Mueller Scam begins!" Trump posted on Twitter, after Sessions fell short of securing a majority in the Republican primary in the Senate race.
For months, Trump has told aides he believes he can shape the Democratic race to his own advantage by focusing on specific candidates. And he has been more overt than any incumbent in trying to influence the nominating contest of another party, training his Twitter feed on his potential rivals and trying to deepen authentic divisions in the Democratic Party by stoking fears that the establishment was trying to rob Sanders of the nomination.
He floated the idea in January that the Senate impeachment trial was designed to keep Sanders grounded in Washington instead of campaigning in Iowa ahead of the caucuses there.
That month, Trump aides also began to see Sanders as their ideal Democratic opponent in November and sought to elevate his profile.
Another target was Michael Bloomberg, a longtime rival from New York who had no compunction contrasting his wealth with Trump's.
Bloomberg's withdrawal from the race Wednesday may provide Trump with a small measure of comfort. But it also presents a challenge for his campaign, as Bloomberg has promised to spend $1 billion to help the Democratic nominee and threw his support to Biden.
But Bloomberg was not the main concern of Trump and his advisers. For months, they fanned the flames about Biden's younger son, Hunter, and his work for Burisma, an energy company in Ukraine. That effort was central to the impeachment inquiry into whether Trump tried to pressure Ukrainians to investigate the Bidens in exchange for releasing military aid.
The damage to Trump was obvious, but the former vice president's candidacy also suffered in the process.
But the revival of Biden - who was buoyed by black voters, a core Democratic Party constituency, in several states - illustrates the limits of Trump's influence.
"I think Democratic primary voters are numbing to Trump's buffoonery - black voters in particular," said Addisu Demissie, who managed Sen. Cory Booker's presidential campaign. "They are the ones who have breathed life back into Biden's campaign and, if anything, they may relish seeing Biden take him down."
Caption: President Trump's aides are preparing for a scorched-earth campaign against Joe Biden.
DOUG MILLS/The New York Times

____________________________________________________________

Early votes can be wasted on candidates who drop out

Autor: Maxwell, Scott; Sentinel Columnist. 

Información de publicación: Orlando Sentinel ; Orlando, Fla. [Orlando, Fla]. 05 Mar 2020: B.1.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/early-votes-can-be-wasted-on-candidates-who-drop/docview/2370979828/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Early+votes+can+be+wasted+on+candidates+who+drop+out&amp;author=Maxwell%2C+Scott%3BSentinel+Columnist&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=B.1&amp;date=2020-03-05&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Orlando+Sentinel&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Asoutheastnews_

Texto completo: Holy moly, we're chock full o' news today. With the presidential primary in full swing, the coronavirus threatening and Florida's legislative session heading for overtime, we've got more bits of tid than a cat has lives ... or at least than Democrats have left running for president.
Let's start with some numbers.
16. That's how many candidates local Democrats will see on their presidential primary ballots March 17.
4. That's how many of those 16 are still actually running campaigns, according to Orange County Elections Supervisor Bill Cowles. (Who emphatically qualified that statement by stressing: "That's as of 12:06 PM on Wednesday, March 4.")
More than 300,000. That's how many Florida Democrats mailed in ballots before last weekend - more than two weeks before the election and, more important, before four of the big names in the race dropped out.
More than 400,000. That's how many Californians cast votes for candidates who had dropped out of the race before the Election Day polls even opened out there.
Listen, I understand the eagerness to cast a ballot. I don't quite get the eagerness to do so before you even know who's officially running or if your ballot will count.
1. That's the number of candidates who dropped out of the race while I was writing a column about candidates dropping out of the race.
On to other news ...
Coronavirus tip, Cajun-style. This comes courtesy of ABCNews reporter Kaylee Hartung, a Louisiana native: "Wash your hands like you just finished eating crawfish and you need to take your contacts out!"
Nestle wants water. Perhaps you've seen the feel-good TV ads that feature a worker at one of Nestle's bottled-water plants talking about how her company pumps millions of dollars into Florida's economy. Several suspicious readers have asked if there's a reason they're seeing that ad. You bet your aquifer there is. Nestle wants a permit to drain up to 1.1 million gallons of water a day. So is this a good idea for a state with water issues? Well, the Gainesville Sun reports that the Suwannee River Water Management District's own experts have recommended against the idea. And eco-advocates have raised also raised objections. But in Florida, rarely are either of those things considered deal-breakers. So we'll see.
Sad this is even needed. You may have seen that legislators filed a bill to stop cops in Florida from handcuffing and arresting 6-year-old children. How very Florida that such a bill is even needed. However, what's even more Florida is that it now looks like the bill may not pass. Be careful out there, first-graders.
Sad this is even needed, part 2. Another bill would prevent judges from imprisoning citizens who oversleep on jury-duty day. This one was filed after a South Florida judge made national news for imprisoning a man who (you guessed it) overslept on jury-duty day. In other words, you live in a state where potential jurors sometimes get tougher sentences than the criminals whose cases they decide. This one might pass.
Pander. Cave in. Repeat. You've probably seen the movie "Groundhog Day" where Bill Murray wakes up every day to the exact same scenario. It's similar to GOP legislators who claim every year they're going to defund Visit Florida. Each year, chest-thumping politicians claim they're going to take on Big Tourism and fight corporate welfare. And then every year, those same politicians follow Big Tourism's marching orders to give them your tax dollars for that welfare. Guys, we know how this movie ends. At least "Groundhog Day" was entertaining.
UCF Prez: Experience needed? Speaking of Visit Florida, one of the odder applicants for UCF president is Ken Lawson, a former Visit Florida CEO and legislator who now runs Gov. Ron DeSantis' economic-development division. At first glance, Lawson would seem to be wildly unqualified for this higher-ed post ... since his resume suggests he has no actual experience working in higher-ed. But what Lawson lacks in experience, he makes up for in political connections. So don't rule him out.
Let's end with a few more politics-by-numbers
1. That's how many of Central Florida's congressional reps keep getting mentioned as possible running mate. We're talking about Val Demings. The New York Times was among the latest to mention Demings, who just finished up a stint as a House manager for the impeachment effort.
2. The number of presidential candidates Orlando Mayor Buddy Dyer endorsed in less than 24 hours.
530,000. That's how many Republicans have already mailed in their ballots. How big of a number is that? Well, that's more mail-in votes from Republicans - with nearly two weeks left - than Democrats mailed during all of 2016. And keep in mind: Republicans don't even really have a primary race this year. (Yes, President Trump has opponents named on the ballot. But those challengers have as much a chance of winning the GOP nomination as I do.) That means Florida Republicans who are flooding elections offices with ballots aren't really making a decision as much as they are making a statement. And that statement seems to be they are revved and ready.
smaxwell@orlandosentinel.com
Caption: PHOTO: "I can remember when I did not have the right to vote," said Nancy Glenn Griesinger, second from right, when asked why she waited so long in line to vote Tuesday at Texas Southern University in Houston.
Jon Shapley/AP

Deadlocked in three elections, Israel seeks ways to avert 4th

Autor: Halbfinger, David M. 

Información de publicación: South Florida Sun - Sentinel ; Fort Lauderdale, Fla. [Fort Lauderdale, Fla]. 05 Mar 2020: A.9.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/deadlocked-three-elections-israel-seeks-ways/docview/2370979771/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Deadlocked+in+three+elections%2C+Israel+seeks+ways+to+avert+4th&amp;author=Halbfinger%2C+David+M&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.9&amp;date=2020-03-05&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=South+Florida+Sun+-+Sentinel&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Asoutheastnews_

Texto completo: JERUSALEM - With Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's supporters for another term outnumbered by lawmakers who want him gone, Israel's political system - having cranked through the motions of a third election in less than a year only to produce another stalemate - began grappling Wednesday with what to do next.
A nearly complete vote count showed Netanyahu's coalition of right-wing and religious parties with 58 seats in the 120-seat Parliament, three short of a governing majority.
That leaves Israel more or less back at square one - except that Netanyahu's trial on felony corruption charges starts March 17, his opponents appear exhausted by a campaign in which he outclassed them to achieve a solid plurality and no one in the country appears willing to contemplate a fourth ballot.
Netanyahu's Likud party sought to maximize its leverage as the largest faction to emerge from Monday's election, floating the possibility of its recruiting right-leaning lawmakers from the mostly left-leaning Labor-Gesher-Meretz alliance or from the centrist Blue and White party, headed by the former army chief Benny Gantz, who was Netanyahu's leading challenger.
But just one defector - whose political career could be ended, analysts said, by such a betrayal of the voters who elected him or her - would be a lot to ask. Three would seem a miracle, even for Netanyahu.
And the likeliest candidates to be wooed by Netanyahu all insisted they were holding fast to their promises to see him into retirement and could not be bought off, no matter the inducement.
The anti-Netanyahu forces, for their part, showed some new fight Wednesday.
Lawmakers from all three center-left parties said they would propose or support legislation to bar Israel's president from asking a lawmaker under indictment to form a government.
Ofer Shelah, of Blue and White, said the party would pursue measures in Parliament to block Netanyahu from serving as prime minister.
He noted that Israeli law now prohibits someone under indictment from serving as an ordinary government minister but does not specifically address the prime minister's position.
"We believe such a law is worthy," Shelah said.
Nitzan Horowitz, leader of the left-wing Meretz party, encouraged Blue and White to "go for it," saying, "It reflects the will of the public, and it's the moral thing to do."
Ahmed Tibi, of the predominantly Arab Joint List, which won a record 15 seats in Parliament on surprisingly strong turnout among Palestinian citizens of Israel, said it, too, would support such a law.
It was not clear whether Avigdor Liberman's ultranationalist Yisrael Beiteinu party, whose support would also be needed, would join in such an effort. His party emerged with seven seats, according to the unfinished tally.
Still, the idea of such a law drew howls from Netanyahu's supporters on the right, who said it would be retroactive and would not survive a court challenge.
Ayelet Shaked, a former justice minister from the right-wing Yamina party, accused the left, "which exalts democracy," of trying to use legislation to "cancel election results," and "with the aid of terror supporters" at that.
The term "terror supporters" referred to the Joint List, some members of which are accused by critics of having expressed sympathy for terrorists. Tibi is widely reviled among many Israeli Jews for, among other things, having been an adviser to Yasser Arafat, the longtime Palestinian leader.
Analysts said it was unlikely that the legislation barring an indicted lawmaker from serving as prime minister would be approved, in part because of the political storm it could kick up. But several suggested that the anti-Netanyahu parties were making a point as the jockeying over coalition talks begins.
Caption: Israeli election vote totals show Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is three seats short of a governing majority.
DAN BALILTY/The New York Times

Materia: Legislation; Legislators; Prime ministers; Elections

Lugar: New York Israel

Personas: Gantz, Benjamin Arafat, Yasser Shaked, Ayelet Netanyahu, Benjamin

____________________________________________________________

Deadlocked in 3 elections, Israel seeks ways to avert 4th

Autor: Halbfinger, David M. 

Información de publicación: Hartford Courant ; Hartford, Conn. [Hartford, Conn]. 05 Mar 2020: A.11.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/deadlocked-3-elections-israel-seeks-ways-avert/docview/2370979749/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Deadlocked+in+3+elections%2C+Israel+seeks+ways+to+avert+4th&amp;author=Halbfinger%2C+David+M&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.11&amp;date=2020-03-05&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Hartford+Courant&amp;issn=1047-4153&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anortheastnews1_

Texto completo: JERUSALEM - With Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's supporters for another term outnumbered by lawmakers who want him gone, Israel's political system - having cranked through the motions of a third election in less than a year only to produce another stalemate - began grappling Wednesday with what to do next.
A nearly complete vote count showed Netanyahu's coalition of right-wing and religious parties with 58 seats in the 120-seat Parliament, three short of a governing majority.
That leaves Israel more or less back at square one - except that Netanyahu's trial on felony corruption charges starts March 17, his opponents appear exhausted by a campaign in which he outclassed them to achieve a solid plurality and no one in the country appears willing to contemplate a fourth ballot.
Netanyahu's Likud party sought to maximize its leverage as the largest faction to emerge from Monday's election, floating the possibility of its recruiting right-leaning lawmakers from the mostly left-leaning Labor-Gesher-Meretz alliance or from the centrist Blue and White party, headed by the former army chief Benny Gantz, who was Netanyahu's leading challenger.
But just one defector - whose political career could be ended, analysts said, by such a betrayal of the voters who elected him or her - would be a lot to ask. Three would seem a miracle, even for Netanyahu.
And the likeliest candidates to be wooed by Netanyahu all insisted they were holding fast to their promises to see him into retirement and could not be bought off, no matter the inducement.
The anti-Netanyahu forces, for their part, showed some new fight Wednesday.
Lawmakers from all three center-left parties said they would propose or support legislation to bar Israel's president from asking a lawmaker under indictment to form a government.
Ofer Shelah, of Blue and White, said the party would pursue measures in Parliament to block Netanyahu from serving as prime minister.
He noted that Israeli law now prohibits someone under indictment from serving as an ordinary government minister but does not specifically address the prime minister's position.
"We believe such a law is worthy," Shelah said.
Nitzan Horowitz, leader of the left-wing Meretz party, encouraged Blue and White to "go for it," saying, "It reflects the will of the public, and it's the moral thing to do."
Ahmed Tibi, of the predominantly Arab Joint List, which won a record 15 seats in Parliament on surprisingly strong turnout among Palestinian citizens of Israel, said it, too, would support such a law.
It was not clear whether Avigdor Liberman's ultranationalist Yisrael Beiteinu party, whose support would also be needed, would join in such an effort. His party emerged with seven seats, according to the unfinished tally.
Still, the idea of such a law drew howls from Netanyahu's supporters on the right, who said it would be retroactive and would not survive a court challenge.
Ayelet Shaked, a former justice minister from the right-wing Yamina party, accused the left, "which exalts democracy," of trying to use legislation to "cancel election results," and "with the aid of terror supporters" at that.
The term "terror supporters" referred to the Joint List, some members of which are accused by critics of having expressed sympathy for terrorists. Tibi is widely reviled among many Israeli Jews for, among other things, having been an adviser to Yasser Arafat, the longtime Palestinian leader.
Analysts said it was unlikely that the legislation barring an indicted lawmaker from serving as prime minister would be approved, in part because of the political storm it could kick up. But several suggested that the anti-Netanyahu parties were making a point as the jockeying over coalition talks begins.
Caption: Israeli election vote totals show Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is three seats short of a governing majority.
DAN BALILTY/The New York Times

Deadlocked in 3 elections, Israel seeks ways to avert 4th

Autor: Halbfinger, David M.
